text:
Some time ago, a website warned about the dangers of public check-ins—when you announce your location online. The message was clear: you might think you're just saying, "Hey, I'm here," but you're also telling everyone, including people you might not want to meet, that you're not at home. This highlighted the growing concern that sharing too much online can have negative effects. The internet offers many exciting opportunities to share our lives with a global audience, promising things like wealth and fame. So, we dive into the online world, sharing personal stories and photos. But soon, we realize it's a crowded and risky place, and we can get lost. 

This might sound discouraging, but don't lose hope. There is guidance from early internet users who explored these challenges before social media existed. These pioneers, the first bloggers, experienced the ups and downs of online life. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with the challenges of being in the public eye. We can learn from their experiences. 

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting online. At that time, the web was mostly used by students and scientists. Hall saw it as a chance to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with text, photos, and art. In 1996, he started a daily blog, attracting readers with his bold approach. Hall shared everything, and anyone who crossed his path could end up on his site. This was the work of an exhibitionist, but it also had artistic value. 

One day, visitors to Hall's site found it replaced with a video called Dark Night. He explained that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He stopped blogging, but the issue remains. Sharing online is great, but if you expect it to make people like you, you'll be disappointed.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job. One day, a colleague sent her blog to the company's vice presidents, including those she had criticized, and she lost her job. This situation is known as the "online distribution effect," where people feel they can say things online they wouldn't say in person. But the internet is not a separate reality where we can speak freely without consequences. Our online and real lives are connected, and ignoring this can lead to serious mistakes.

Armstrong's story ended well. Although she was upset and stopped blogging for a while, she got married and restarted her blog, focusing on her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. She learned to manage what she shares online. Armstrong's experience teaches us that while the internet allows us to say anything, it doesn't mean we should.

Some time ago, scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called "What the Bleep Do We Know?" This film mixed documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe that we don't understand. Most scientists agree with this idea because no one claims to know everything about the universe. However, some scientists felt the need to warn the public about the film, calling it anything from "atrocious" to "a very dangerous piece of work." This made the film seem intriguing. 

At first, the film seemed harmless, with scientists saying that new discoveries show the universe is stranger than we thought. But then the film talked about discoveries like the idea that water molecules can be changed by thoughts. A Japanese researcher supposedly showed that the shape of a water molecule could be changed by the thoughts of people around it. The film showed pictures of ice crystals looking nice after being talked to by someone happy and looking bad after being exposed to someone in a bad mood. Many people find this evidence convincing because it is simple and clear. However, scientists usually respond with skepticism, saying, "Give me a break." 

The idea that thoughts can affect water is amazing and could mean new forces are at work in the universe. But we need solid proof that this effect is real, and pretty pictures of crystals are not enough. The real issue is that the film's claims were not strange enough. Consider this: water molecules might have properties due to a form of energy that comes from nowhere and is linked to a force driving the universe's expansion. This idea is supported by decades of research in labs and observatories worldwide. 

Recent discoveries show that the universe is indeed stranger than we thought. Astronomers have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and is driven by a mysterious force called "dark energy." On a more practical level, neuroscientists have found that our conscious perception of events is delayed by about half a second, but our brains edit this delay out. Anthropologists think they have found where modern humans originated and how they spread across the world. Some theorists even suggest there are links between life on Earth and the universe's fundamental design.

Science is far from complete. In fact, we seem further from knowing everything than ever before. Concepts like chaos and quantum uncertainty limit what we can know. Some of the world's top theoretical physicists are working on a "Theory of Everything" to explain all the forces and particles in the universe with one equation. Despite these theories, many people believe the universe can be summed up in one word: incredible.

In simple terms, I find writing novels challenging, but writing short stories is enjoyable. Writing a novel is like planting a forest, while writing a short story is like planting a garden. Both activities complement each other, creating a complete landscape that I value. The trees provide shade, and the wind moves the leaves, which sometimes turn a bright gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and their colorful petals attract bees and butterflies, showing the change of seasons. Since I started my career as a fiction writer, I have alternated between writing novels and short stories. My routine is this: after finishing a novel, I want to write short stories; after completing short stories, I focus on a novel. I never mix the two; I don't write short stories while working on a novel and vice versa. Writing these two forms might use different parts of the brain, and it takes time to switch from one to the other. After starting my career with two short novels in 1975, I began writing short stories from 1984 to 1985. I didn't know much about writing short stories then, so it was difficult, but the experience was memorable. It expanded my fictional world, and readers liked seeing this different side of me. One of my early works, ‘Breaking Waves’, was in my first short-story collection, Tales from Abroad. This was my beginning as a short-story writer. One joy of writing short stories is that they don't take long to finish. It usually takes me about a week to get a short story into decent shape, though revisions can be endless. It's not like the long commitment needed for a novel, which can take a year or two. You go into a room, finish your work, and leave. That's it. Writing a novel can feel like it goes on forever, and I sometimes wonder if I'll make it through. So, writing short stories is a necessary change of pace for me. Another nice thing about short stories is that you can create them from small things – an idea, a word, an image, anything. It's often like jazz improvisation, with the story leading me. Also, with short stories, you don't have to worry about failing. If an idea doesn't work out, you just move on. Even great writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver didn't create masterpieces every time. This is comforting. You can learn from your mistakes and use that in the next story. When I write novels, I try to learn from the successes and failures of my short stories. In this way, short stories are like an experimental lab for me as a novelist. It's hard to experiment in a novel, so without short stories, writing novels would be even harder. My short stories are like soft shadows I've set out in the world, faint footprints I've left behind. I remember where I wrote each one and how I felt. Short stories are like guideposts to my heart, and it makes me happy to share these feelings with my readers.

Science can be both very theoretical, like philosophy, and very practical, like curing diseases. It has made our lives easier but also posed threats to our existence. Science tries to understand everything from tiny ants to the vast universe, but it often struggles to fully grasp these concepts. It influences poets, politicians, philosophers, and even tricksters. Its beauty is often only seen by experts, its dangers are misunderstood, and its importance is both overestimated and underestimated. People often ignore its mistakes or exaggerate them. 

The journey to explain the universe has been full of conflict. Old theories are often changed or completely overturned, much like how new music styles are initially mocked but later become popular. The fight between old and new ideas is rarely graceful. Scientists can be driven by jealousy and anger. The history of science is marked by conflict. This book will explore how scientific ideas have changed not just science but also human thought. While science has practical benefits, this book will focus on the ideas themselves. We will admire their beauty and creativity but also question them, recognizing both human ingenuity and limitations.

Science is always changing. Scientists are constantly disproving each other's ideas. Usually, these changes don't affect society much, but sometimes they lead to major shifts in our beliefs. For example, in the 17th century, science described the universe as a giant clock. Three centuries later, physics challenged this view, suggesting that observing the universe changes it and that we don't fully understand our basic concepts. Some people see the changing nature of science as a weakness, but it usually leads to better understanding and prediction of nature. Isaac Newton could explain more than Aristotle, and Albert Einstein more than Newton. Science often makes mistakes but continues to progress.

At the end of the 19th century, many physicists thought there was nothing significant left to discover. Then came radioactivity, X-rays, the electron, the nucleus, hundreds of new particles, quantum mechanics, relativity, antimatter, dark matter, black holes, chaos theory, the Big Bang, and more. Biology has also made many discoveries. Today, some claim we are close to a "theory of everything" that explains the universe. Maybe. 

Science is not just an intellectual hobby. In the last two centuries, we have gone from observing nature to controlling it, sometimes upsetting the natural balance without understanding the consequences. Science needs to be monitored. Non-scientists can no longer ignore scientific advances, as they will shape the world their children will live in and the kind of children they will have. Science is now part of how humanity plans and shapes its future. Deciding how to shape the future is not just for philosophers; these decisions can impact national budgets, the health of future generations, and even the survival of life on Earth.

Starting around 2015, after years of growth, major publishers noticed that ebook sales had stopped increasing or even decreased. This raised doubts about the future of ebooks in the publishing industry. An anonymous publishing executive admitted that the excitement around ebooks might have led to poor investment decisions, as his company lost faith in the traditional printed book. Despite the clear evidence that digital and print books can coexist, the question of whether ebooks will replace print books keeps coming up. Whether people are predicting or dismissing this idea, the thought of books disappearing continues to capture our imagination and spark debate. Why is this idea so compelling? Why do we see the relationship between ebooks and print books as a battle, even when evidence suggests otherwise? The answers go beyond ebooks and reveal our mixed feelings of excitement and fear about innovation and change. In my research, I have explored how the idea of one medium replacing another often follows the introduction of new technologies. Even before digital technologies, critics predicted the end of existing media. For example, when television was invented, many thought radio would die, but radio survived by finding new uses, like being listened to in cars and on factory floors. The idea of books disappearing isn't new either. As early as 1894, people speculated that the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This pattern has repeated many times. Movies, radio, television, hyperlinks, and smartphones have all been seen as threats to print books. Some believed the end of books would lead to cultural decline, while others exaggerated the benefits of ebooks. The idea of the death of the book often appears during times of technological change. This narrative reflects our hopes and fears about technological change. To understand why these reactions are common, we must consider that we form emotional connections with media as they become part of our lives. Studies show we develop close bonds with objects like books, TVs, and computers, even naming our cars or getting frustrated with our laptops. So, when new technology like e-readers emerges, it doesn't just mean economic and social change; it also affects our bond with something integral to our daily lives. As technology advances, we long for what we used to know but no longer have. This is why industries develop around retro products and older technologies. For example, the spread of the printing press in 15th-century Europe made people seek out original manuscripts. The shift from silent to sound movies in the 1920s created nostalgia for silent films. The same happened with the move from analog to digital photography and from vinyl records to CDs. Not surprisingly, e-readers have led to a renewed appreciation for the physical quality of 'old' books, even their sometimes unpleasant smell. This should reassure those worried about the disappearance of print books. However, the idea of a disappearing medium will continue to be an appealing story about the power of technology and our resistance to change. One way we make sense of change is by using familiar narrative patterns, like stories of tragedy and endings. These stories are easy to remember and share, and the story of the death of the book reflects both our excitement for the future and our fear of losing parts of our intimate world—and ultimately, ourselves.

For a year and a half, almost every weekday morning, I woke up at 5:30, brushed my teeth, made coffee, and sat down to write. I focused on how some of the greatest minds from the past 400 years managed their daily routines to be creative and productive. By exploring the everyday details of their lives—like when they slept, ate, and worked—I aimed to offer a fresh perspective on their personalities and careers. I wanted to show that these famous figures were creatures of habit, just like us. 

The French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, "Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are." I say, "Tell me what time you eat, and if you take a nap afterward." This book is about the conditions that support creative work, not the work itself. It’s about the process, not the meaning. But it’s also personal. The novelist John Cheever believed that even a business letter reveals something about the writer’s inner self. I agree.

In this book, I explore questions I struggle with myself: How can you do meaningful creative work while earning a living? Is it better to focus entirely on a project or to dedicate a small part of each day to it? When time is limited, do you have to give up things like sleep or income, or can you learn to be more efficient? I don’t claim to have all the answers, but I provide examples of how successful people have faced these challenges. I wanted to show how big creative ideas are built from small daily actions and how our habits affect our work.

The book is called "Daily Rituals," but it’s really about routines. Routines might seem ordinary or thoughtless, like being on autopilot. However, a good routine can help you use your limited resources—like time, willpower, and optimism—effectively. A solid routine can guide your mental energy and help you avoid being controlled by your moods. Psychologist William James believed that forming good habits allows us to focus on more interesting activities. Ironically, James himself struggled with procrastination and couldn’t stick to a schedule.

This book was born from my own procrastination. One Sunday, instead of writing a story due the next day, I was tidying my office and making coffee. I’m a morning person, focused in the early hours but not so much after lunch. To feel better about this, I started looking online for other writers’ schedules. I found them fascinating and thought someone should collect these stories. That’s how I started the Daily Routines blog, which eventually led to this book.

The blog was informal; I posted descriptions of people’s routines as I found them in biographies and articles. For the book, I expanded and researched more thoroughly, keeping the variety and brevity that made the blog popular. I let my subjects speak for themselves through quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. In other cases, I summarized their routines from other sources. This book wouldn’t have been possible without the work of many biographers, journalists, and scholars. I’ve documented all my sources in the Notes section, which can also guide further reading.

Howard became a palaeontologist because of an unexpected change in his family's plans when he was six years old. His father, who was very careful with money, decided they couldn't afford a holiday to Spain due to rising interest rates. Instead, they rented a small house on the English coast. One rainy August day, Howard found an ammonite on the beach. This discovery sparked his interest in becoming a palaeontologist. By the end of his university studies, he knew he wanted to focus on the earliest periods of life, not on dinosaurs or the Jurassic period. He was fascinated by the beginnings of life, studying ancient, delicate creatures in rocks.

After finishing his doctoral thesis, Howard worried about finding a job, especially in a place he wanted to work. He was confident in his abilities but knew that getting a job wasn't always fair. When a teaching position at Tavistock College in London opened, he applied, though he wasn't very hopeful. On the day of his interview, the professor who was supposed to support another candidate couldn't attend due to an accident. The replacement professor disliked the absent professor and made sure Howard got the job instead. Howard was surprised and grateful, even after learning the real reason he was chosen. He was slightly disappointed but happy to have the job he wanted.

Howard often thought about how his professional life was orderly, with clear plans and goals, unlike the unpredictable nature of personal life. He realized how strangers could unexpectedly change his life, like when his briefcase with lecture notes was stolen at an Underground station. Frustrated, he returned to the college, postponed his lecture, and reported the theft. While having coffee with a colleague and a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi, he learned about a new collection of fossils that needed study. This opportunity became his biggest challenge and secured his career. If not for the theft, he wouldn't have known about it. He quickly changed his plans, deciding not to attend a conference in Stockholm or take students on a field trip to Scotland. Instead, he focused on finding the funds to visit the museum in Nairobi.

Charles Spence is willing to try almost any food. In his office at Oxford University, he mentions having ice cream made from bee larvae at home. Although they look like maggots, they taste 'slightly nutty and floral.' Making insects a normal part of our diet is just one of the challenges Spence and his team are working on. Spence studies how our senses work together to create the flavors we experience. His research is quietly but significantly changing what we eat and drink, from big food companies to top restaurant menus. 

Spence and his colleagues are part of a field called gastrophysics, which examines in detail how we experience food and drink. Factors like who we eat with, how food is presented, the color and texture of plates, and background noise all influence taste. In his book, "The Perfect Meal," co-authored with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, Spence shares many interesting insights. For example, the first person to order in a restaurant tends to enjoy their meal the most. Also, we eat about 35% more when dining with one other person, and 75% more with three others.

Spence's lab at Oxford is simple and not high-tech. It includes soundproof booths and old audio-visual equipment. By keeping costs low, he can collaborate creatively with chefs who can't afford academic research. Much of his work is funded by a large food company. In the past, research funded by industry was seen as less serious in universities. However, now that universities need to show their work has real-world impact, this type of research is more valued. 

Spence is helping well-known brands reduce salt and sugar, often due to government regulations. Companies do this gradually so customers don't notice the change. Research shows that if people are told about the changes, they focus on the taste and may not like it as much.

Spence first met Heston Blumenthal, a famous experimental chef, while working on a project for a major food producer. At the time, people thought science and food didn't mix well, but most food is scientific. Blumenthal and Spence worked together on a dish called 'Sound of the Sea' at Blumenthal's restaurant. Spence notes that the Italian futurists were experimenting with sound and food a century ago, but it didn't become popular.

Now, the food industry is using Spence's sensory science widely. For example, his research shows that high-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, while low-pitched sounds make it taste bitter. An airline will soon pair music with meals served to passengers. Last year, a brand released an app that played music while ice cream softened, but they didn't match the music to the taste, which Spence says is a common oversight.

At home, Spence's dinner parties are quite experimental. They've eaten rabbit with fur on the cutlery and used remote-controlled lights. They've also tested different drinks with sound to see if they have different pitches. For Spence, home, shops, food events, and international conferences are all extensions of his lab.

Our brains are busier than ever. We are bombarded with facts, fake facts, chatter, and rumors, all pretending to be information. We have to sort through this to find what we need and what we can ignore. At the same time, we are doing more tasks ourselves. Thirty years ago, travel agents booked our flights, and salespeople helped us in stores. Now, we do most things on our own. We juggle many roles while trying to manage our lives, families, careers, hobbies, and TV shows, with the help of our smartphones. These devices encourage us to fill every spare moment with activity. However, there's a problem. We think we are multitasking, doing several things at once, but this is a misleading and risky belief. Earl Miller, a neuroscientist at MIT, explains that our brains are not designed to multitask well. When we think we are multitasking, we are actually switching quickly between tasks, which has a mental cost. We are not expert jugglers; we are more like amateur plate spinners, quickly moving from one task to another, worried that something will go wrong. Even though we think we are achieving a lot, multitasking actually makes us less efficient. It increases stress hormones like cortisol and adrenaline, which can overstimulate the brain and cause confusion. Multitasking creates a craving for distraction, rewarding the brain for losing focus. The prefrontal cortex, a part of the brain, is easily distracted by new things, like shiny objects that attract infants. This is ironic because we need this part of the brain to stay focused. Just having the chance to multitask can harm our thinking. Glenn Wilson, a former psychology professor, calls this info-mania. His research shows that trying to focus on a task while an unread email sits in your inbox can lower your IQ by almost 10 points. Wilson found that the mental losses from multitasking are worse than those from being tired. Russ Poldrack, a neuroscientist at Stanford, discovered that learning new information while multitasking sends it to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework while watching TV, the information goes to the striatum, which stores new skills, instead of the hippocampus, which organizes facts and ideas. Without TV, the information is stored in the hippocampus, making it easier to remember. Multitasking also involves making decisions, like whether to answer a text or ignore it. Decision-making is hard on our brains, and small decisions use the same mental resources as big ones. After making many small decisions, we can end up making poor choices about important things. When discussing information overload with business leaders, scientists, and writers, email is often mentioned as a problem. It's not about email itself, but the overwhelming amount of communication. A colleague's 10-year-old son said his father "answers emails" for a living, which is not far from the truth. We feel we must reply to emails, but it seems impossible to do so and accomplish other tasks.

In a Swedish zoo, a chimpanzee named Santino would break concrete at night to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In the US, female bats help other bats give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, these questions were not considered important. Scientists focused on animal behaviors and their outcomes, not on whether animals had feelings or morals. But recently, this has started to change. Research on animals like bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens has begun to explore animal emotions. This shift has led to popular science books like Mark Bekoff’s "Wild Justice" and Victoria Braithwaite’s "Do Fish Feel Pain?". These books have sparked a debate: do animals have consciousness? This leads to another question: do animals have a sense of right and wrong? 

In a recent experiment, cows had to open a locked gate to get food. Those that opened the gate themselves showed more happiness by jumping and kicking than those that had help. If cows enjoy solving problems, what does this mean for eating beef? The observations are clear, but their meaning is debated. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, author of "Second Nature," believes the logical response is to stop eating meat. He thinks humanity is on the brink of a major ethical change, like the end of slavery. Aubrey Manning, a professor at Edinburgh University, suggests we should rethink how we view animal intelligence. He believes animals have a simpler version of our mind. Professor Euan MacPhail argues we should stop attributing human traits to animals. The disagreement is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. Since defining consciousness is difficult, can we ever truly understand what it’s like to be a bat?

Balcombe describes an experiment with starlings, a type of bird, that he believes shows they can feel depressed. At Newcastle University, starlings were split into two groups. One group lived in spacious, comfortable cages, while the other group lived in small, empty cages. Both groups were initially fed tasty worms from one box and unpleasant worms from another. They learned to eat only from the tasty box. Later, when only unpleasant worms were offered, only the birds in the comfortable cages ate them. Balcombe concluded that the birds in the poor cages became pessimistic. Balcombe, who has worked with animal rights groups, has a clear bias. He says, "We look back with horror at times of racism. One day, we will feel the same about how we treat animals. We can’t support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger." If Balcombe were the only one with this view, it might be easy to dismiss him as extreme. But Professor Aubrey Manning shares his views. Manning, who wrote a textbook on animal behavior, says, "We are seeing a change. In the early 20th century, people thought animals thought like us, and there was a reaction against that. Now, we are swinging back. But it’s a controversial topic, and we should avoid letting personal opinions influence the discussion."

Critical thinking, also known as analytical thinking, is a way of engaging with what we read or hear to understand it more deeply. Adrian West, a research director at the Edward de Bono Foundation U.K. and a former computer science lecturer, notes that people often believe argument helps find the truth. While technology helps us store and process information, there is concern that it changes how we solve complex problems and makes deep thinking harder. West points out that we are bombarded with poor but appealing ideas and opinions, which can overwhelm our ability to reason. Interestingly, having more data doesn't necessarily lead to better knowledge or decisions. Despite this, West finds it surprising that our thinking quality hasn't been greatly affected.

The National Endowment for the Arts reports a 10% decline in literary reading, with the decline speeding up. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, believes that focusing more on visual media has a cost. She suggests that less reading might lead to weaker critical thinking because people now focus more on real-time media and multitasking instead of concentrating on one thing. However, there is no clear answer yet on how technology affects critical thinking. Technology's growing presence has made it difficult for academics to rely on their previous beliefs. Computers, video games, and the internet can have both positive and negative effects, depending on how they are used. For instance, a computer game might either help or hinder critical thinking. Reading online can improve analytical skills, but constantly clicking on links might prevent deeper thought.

Greenfield, who reviewed over 50 studies on learning and technology, says that technology changes how people think. She notes that reading enhances imagination and critical thinking in ways that visual media like video games and TV do not. Reading helps develop imagination, reflection, and vocabulary. However, she also found that visual media can improve some types of information processing. Unfortunately, most visual media are real-time and don't allow time for reflection or analysis. As a result, many people, especially younger ones, may not reach their full potential.

How society views technology influences its perception of critical thinking. This is especially true with video games and cognition. James Paul Gee, an educational psychology professor, argues that video and computer games are not just entertainment but also valuable learning tools. Evidence shows that games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and analytical skills in realistic virtual environments. These games allow players to explore ideas that might be hard to access otherwise. In the digital age, as reading and math scores drop, it's important to understand how technology affects thinking and analysis.

Matthew Crawford, when not writing about how we should live, works as a motorcycle mechanic. He chose this job after feeling unhappy with office work and his role in social policy institutions. His first book praised the benefits of manual work, while his latest book is about dealing with modern life. He got the idea for this book while shopping, noticing ads on a credit card machine during a short delay. Crawford realized that these constant demands on our attention are hard to escape. We should be able to decide what we focus on, but often we can't because of things we're not fully aware of. It's becoming harder to think or remember past conversations. To avoid constant interruptions, people tend to isolate themselves and avoid simple interactions like talking to strangers. Crawford points out that we often experience the world through things like video games and phone apps, which can manipulate us and take over our desires. Many people share his concerns. For example, office workers often complain about emails but then spend their free time checking them. Studies show that just having a phone visible can distract us, a common experience for those who feel drawn to their phones during dinner. There's no scientific proof yet that our attention spans are shorter, but we are more aware of other things we could be doing. While it might seem like technology is the problem, Crawford believes it has just made it easier for us to focus on ourselves. With so many choices, our self-control is tested, affecting our social interactions. We prefer texting friends to avoid real conversations. By only interacting with digital versions of people, we risk losing something important in society. Screens are only part of the issue. Crawford uses his gym as an example. It used to have one music player for everyone, which could cause disagreements. Now, people listen to their own music with earbuds, making the gym less social. Real connections often happen through resolving conflicts, like different music tastes. Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we need rules to reduce noise and distractions in public spaces. More importantly, he recommends engaging in skilled activities to connect with the world meaningfully. He mentions cooks, ice-hockey players, and motorbike racers as examples of people who deal with real-world challenges. These roles require good judgment and managing others in the same space. Engaging with the world this way makes artificial experiences seem less appealing. This doesn't mean everyone should become a chef, but it's important to use your judgment. There are many benefits, including professional satisfaction. Constantly fighting distractions is tiring and makes it hard to focus on important things. Focusing on one thing helps you pay attention to others.

Text: The question "What do you do for a living?" is common in small talk, and people often define themselves by their jobs. For most, it's easy to answer, but for a philosopher like me, it's a bit more complicated. Calling oneself a philosopher can sound pretentious because it might suggest having access to some higher truth, which is not the case. Philosophers are just like everyone else, but this stereotype persists. 

One reason for this stereotype is that philosophers are seen as people who judge others' actions and value intellectual life. Aristotle, a Greek philosopher, believed that a life of contemplation was the most virtuous. While few modern philosophers agree, philosophy is still associated with deep thinking. Socrates, another Greek philosopher, said, "The unexamined life is not worth living," meaning that blindly following cultural norms is unsatisfying. Reflecting on life helps us make our own decisions. However, living an examined life doesn't mean reading philosophical classics or dedicating life to intellectual reflection. It means looking closely at everyday experiences to see if they deserve their importance. It doesn't require living like a sage, isolated from society. Instead, it's practical and involves sharing knowledge, which is essential for a good life.

Another reason for the misconception about philosophers is that academic philosophy has become distant from everyday life, especially for those without formal training. This isn't entirely philosophers' fault; university funding and evaluations focus on expensive, hard-to-access journals. This limits philosophers' ability to share ideas beyond a small group of experts. To outsiders, philosophy can seem disconnected from reality. While philosophers once challenged this view, many now accept it. The university system created this isolation, and academics have supported it. As philosophy becomes more focused on specific debates, explaining these ideas to non-experts is difficult. In some areas, philosophy has withdrawn from society, and this needs to change.

I sometimes call myself an "ethicist" because I work in ethics, which evaluates human actions. But this title feels insufficient because ethics is often linked to formal codes and laws. Recently, ethics has come to mean applied ethics, which looks at the fairness of social practices. Ethicists today decide if an action is "ethical" or acceptable. These are important questions, and I often engage with them. However, philosophy is more than this. A typical discussion might start with whether illegally downloading films is unethical (it is) and then explore ideas about responsibility, attitudes towards art, and consumerism. Philosophy helps people examine the practices and behaviors that shape their lives. This might confirm what we already know or show that our beliefs are hard to justify. Either way, by examining these ideas, we contribute to everyone's benefit.

Food lovers, chefs, and those who appreciate food might think that thinking deeply about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. Historically, though, philosophers have often used food as a way to discuss other topics. When philosophers talked about eating, it was usually a metaphor for something else, like gaining knowledge. Sometimes, discussions that seem to be about food are actually about other, loosely related ideas. 

Take the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus, for example. He believed in seeking pleasure and avoiding pain in all areas of life. However, his name has become closely linked with a love for eating and drinking. We see his name used in restaurants, food shops, and recipe websites, likely because these businesses hope to gain credibility by associating with a famous philosopher. 

Food is inherently social and cultural. It doesn't just appear; it comes from historical backgrounds and is shared with others in our communities. These communities provide dining companions and the systems for growing and distributing food. We interact with food more often and in more basic ways than any other product, making it a natural topic for philosophical study.

Once food is prepared, critics start discussing and writing about it. But why do they have such a special status? One philosopher pointed out that tasting food is not a unique skill; rather, food critics are just better at describing tastes. Philosophically, the way we perceive taste hasn't been studied much, as most research has focused on vision. This needs to change.

Another aspect of food is its aesthetics. We often call paintings or music beautiful, but not food. Some philosophers argue that with modern cooking, food deserves a place in discussions about beauty, like sculpture or poetry. However, food is eaten and destroyed in the process, unlike art or music, which lasts over time. So, it's incorrect to think of food as an object of aesthetic value.

There are many ethical questions related to food. We can ask what we should eat: organic, free-range, locally grown, vegetarian, or non-genetically modified foods? Our choices often reflect our ethical beliefs, and philosophers explore why we make these choices, which is a valid area of study.

Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. Home cooks have a special responsibility to their guests because of personal relationships. In home kitchens, everyone shares food and companionship. Professional cooks, however, have duties to their employers and the food itself. Their kitchens are for qualified staff, and their relationships are professional, not personal.

A recent essay called ‘Diplomacy of the Dish’ looks at how food and dining can help bridge cultural gaps. This happens in two ways: by appreciating others' food and by forming personal connections through shared meals, a practice with a long history in diplomacy. The essay includes many interesting examples and stories, making this part of food philosophy engaging for readers.

Rob Daviau, an American game designer, creates 'legacy' board games. He felt that the board games he played as a child were no longer fun or challenging. This led him to think about how board games could change. Could they have a story? Could choices made in one game affect future games? He took a classic game called Risk and made a new version called Risk Legacy. In this version, decisions made during the game have lasting effects. Players might have to tear up cards, mark the board, or open packets with new rules at certain times. The game is played over a set number of sessions, and personal rivalries become part of the game. Daviau said, ‘You could point to the board and say: “Right here! You did this!”’

Daviau was later asked to help create a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players work together to stop diseases. His next project was a game called SeaFall. While Pandemic Legacy was praised, SeaFall was seen as a real test of the legacy format because it was not based on an existing game. Set in the age of sail (16th – mid 19th century), players explore and conquer new lands. Legacy game designers must think about all possible player choices to keep the story intact. They hire testers to see how the game plays out. Jaime Barriga, a tester for SeaFall, said, ‘It takes a lot of time. Sometimes the first few games are great, but then it starts to fall apart, and you have to fix everything.’

Legacy board games were not expected to become popular. Even Daviau thought it would be a niche interest. He said, ‘I thought it was different and good, but strange and unexpected. I thought only a few people would like it.’ However, many players, like Russell Chapman, loved the idea. He sees it as a major advancement in game design. ‘It’s a new level of commitment, intensity, and excitement,’ he said. ‘There’s nothing more exciting for a board gamer than learning a new game or way to play, and legacy games offer that constantly.’

Another fan, Ben Hogg, said the unfolding adventure was more important than concerns about the game's longevity. ‘At first, I was worried about changing and damaging the board,’ he said. ‘But Pandemic Legacy changed that. Most people don’t watch the same movie twice. You’re buying an experience. It adds a story element like video games.’ The legacy format is influenced by video games and the trend for episodic entertainment from TV series. Daviau once wanted to be a TV writer but ended up in advertising and then game design. The desire to tell stories stayed with him. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock compares designing a legacy game to writing a novel. ‘You need to know how it ends and begins,’ he said. ‘But you also need more than just an outline.’

While Daviau feels proud of his work, he is curious to see how others will develop the idea. But he also thinks people might soon want something new. Colby Dauch, who manages the studio that published SeaFall, believes the legacy format has changed how people think about board games. ‘It’s the kind of idea that changes what a board game can be,’ he said.

One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and squeezed into a drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story, which sounds like something from a children's movie, became very popular online. People enjoy stories like this because they like to imagine animals behaving like humans. This is especially true for octopuses, which are very intelligent despite looking so different from us. They can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells as armor, and even play in complex ways.

Many people think that attributing human traits to animals is unscientific. However, Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies primates like gorillas and chimpanzees, argues that the real problem is "anthropodenial"—the refusal to see human-like traits in animals. He has studied animal behavior for decades and found that animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, being self-aware, and understanding others' motives. In other words, animals are much smarter than we often think.

De Waal believes that ignoring animal intelligence is a modern idea. In medieval and early modern Europe, people thought animals were smart enough to be put on trial for crimes. Even in the nineteenth century, scientists looked for connections between human and animal intelligence. Charles Darwin, who developed the theory of evolution, said that the difference between human and animal minds is one of degree, not kind.

In the twentieth century, behaviorism became popular. This approach focused on training animals with rewards and punishments, which led people to see animals as simple machines. Anyone who thought animals had complex inner lives was considered unscientific. This view coincided with a time when humans were destroying animal habitats and ignoring animal welfare.

Fortunately, de Waal thinks we are starting to change our views. We are beginning to see animal intelligence as part of a spectrum that includes humans. He notes that there has been a lot of new information about animal intelligence shared online in recent years. The best tests of animal intelligence consider the unique abilities of each species. For example, squirrels might not do well on human memory tests, but they can remember where they’ve hidden nuts, something humans often struggle with.

In her book "The Soul of an Octopus," naturalist Sy Montgomery suggests that if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might judge us on how many color patterns we can make on our skin. Seeing us fail, it might think we are not very smart.

De Waal is skeptical about Inky's escape story. He thinks it’s unlikely that Inky knew how to find a drain leading to the ocean. However, he acknowledges that viral stories like this can help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once conducted an experiment to see if capuchin monkeys feel envy. When some monkeys received cucumbers and others got grapes, the monkeys with cucumbers became upset. The study was published in a scientific journal, but what really convinced people was a short video of the experiment released ten years later. This shows how our human minds are influenced by stories and visuals.

Robotics, once only seen in science fiction, is now becoming a major technological change, similar to the impact of industrialization. Robots have been used in car manufacturing for years, but experts say we are about to see a big increase in their use across many industries. However, many countries are not ready for this change. Most people agree that robots will take over many jobs in the next 50 years, but they still believe their own jobs will remain the same. This is not true, as robotic automation will affect every industry soon. 

For instance, an Australian company, Fastbrick Robotics, has created a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in an hour, a job that would take two human workers almost a day. In San Francisco, a startup called Simbe Robotics has introduced Tally, a robot that moves through supermarket aisles to check if products are stocked and priced correctly. 

Supporters of robotic automation point out that robots still need humans to service and program them, which could create new, high-skilled jobs. Critics, however, worry that we are not ready for the loss of human interaction in the workplace. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots are changing the workforce. His research shows that soon, many robots will be smarter and able to work with humans. In a few years, many top companies will have a chief robotics officer, and governments will start making laws about robots. Salaries in the robotics field will rise, but there will still be a lack of skilled workers.

Dr. Zhang believes that people with lower skills will be most affected by automation. He suggests that they should not rely on the government to protect their jobs but should instead seek retraining. The idea of having the same job for life is outdated. New developments in robotics will lead to robots that can live with us and interact in more advanced ways, similar to those in science fiction. This presents a great opportunity for businesses but also requires new safety and privacy regulations.

With many jobs at risk, education is key to preparing for the future workforce. Developed countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and maths (STEM) to stay competitive in a changing job market.

George Mallory, a famous mountaineer, once answered the question of why he wanted to climb Mount Everest with, "Because it’s there." This response highlights a common curiosity: why do people risk their lives for something that seems pointless? Mallory's answer might inspire some to follow their dreams, as it challenges people to face the unknown. The real value of his answer is its simplicity, suggesting that climbing might just be about adventure and fun.

In 1967, Bolivian writer Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called ‘Games that Climbers Play’. He described seven different types of climbing activities, each with its own rules, from bouldering to climbing Himalayan peaks. He argued that the style of climbing, like using more or less equipment, should match the rules of the specific climbing activity. Over the years, this idea has become central to discussions about climbing in the West, influencing everything from magazines to debates around campfires.

For many climbers, the love of climbing comes from the sense of freedom it provides. However, climbing can also be very limiting, like being stuck in a tent during a storm. This creates a paradox: climbing can feel both freeing and restricting. Yet, some argue that the simplicity of having limited choices is a form of freedom itself.

US rock climber Joe Fitschen offers a different perspective in his recent essay. He suggests asking "Why do people climb?" instead of just "Why climb?" Fitschen believes climbing is part of our nature, an evolutionary trait that drives us to take on challenges and push our limits, even with risks. The joy of climbing, then, is more about our biology than logic.

US academic Brian Treanor adds another view in his essay. He believes climbing helps develop important virtues like courage, humility, and respect for nature. While not all climbers show these traits, Treanor thinks they are crucial in our modern, risk-averse world. Climbing, therefore, has practical value by helping people develop qualities that are useful in everyday life.

Another idea is that climbers who rely only on themselves, without help from others or technology, must be fully committed to succeed. Expert climbers Ebert and Robinson stirred controversy by suggesting that independent climbs deserve more recognition than those done with large teams or with aids like bottled oxygen. Their essay may have encouraged some climbers to take unnecessary risks.

Finally, looking beyond Western ideas, climbing often involves being in the moment and going with the flow. The physical effort, meditative focus, and intuitive problem-solving are key parts of climbing. Some argue that climbing is similar to Zen practices, which aim to train the mind for peace. This offers another reason why people might be drawn to climbing.

For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel became a leading figure in classical music. He was known as an intellectual and sometimes serious person who focused on European piano music. He wrote and performed a lot but rarely taught. Those close to him saw a playful side, but this was not often shown in his concerts. His life was a constant cycle of study, travel, and performance. 

Then, about four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong approached Brendel after a concert and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel didn't take the request seriously. He had taught very few students and didn't see a reason to start now. He quoted another famous pianist, saying, "You don’t hire a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk." However, something about Kit, who was about 14 at the time, caught his attention. Brendel listened to him play and was impressed. Kit played very well from memory and gave Brendel a CD of a recital where he played beautifully. Brendel thought, "I have to make time for him." Kit's performance was rare because he had a clear understanding of the music and played with great subtlety.

As Brendel steps back from public life, Kit is slowly entering it, with Brendel cautious about him burning out too soon. Kit, now 19, is always busy outside of lessons, learning new languages, studying math, writing computer code, or playing tennis, all under the watchful eye of his mother. He also composes music. Brendel says this is important because writing music helps you understand it better. He noticed Kit has an amazing memory and is a great sight reader. More importantly, Kit listens to his own playing and understands Brendel's instructions, applying them throughout a piece.

Brendel is careful not to raise expectations. He gets upset when newspapers call Kit the future great pianist of the 21st century, saying it's harmful. Like many talented young musicians, Kit plays some things very well, but others need more time and experience. Critics expecting perfection could be damaging.

Now at 80, Brendel is more relaxed in his retirement. He explains that when he was young, he didn't want to be famous quickly but aimed to achieve certain things by 50. By that age, he had done most of them but continued to do more. Although he no longer has the physical strength to play, he still thinks about music and enjoys his new life.

When I was a child, I always thought gardens were magical places. My Grandad’s garden wasn’t in a dirty city; it was by a river and gently sloped down to the water. You couldn’t reach the river, but you could hear the water and birds singing in the trees. I believed all gardens were like this—places of peace and solitude. Grandad’s garden wasn’t fancy. He didn’t have a greenhouse like some neighbors, who made theirs from old window frames. They used plastic to cover broken glass.

At home, my father was often quiet and reserved, but he wasn’t without humor. He liked to say things like, “It’s immaterial to me,” instead of just saying, “I don’t mind.” He probably wished he had achieved more in life. He left school without qualifications and became a plumber, a job he wasn’t passionate about. He wasn’t very ambitious, though he and my mom once considered moving to Canada, but it didn’t happen. However, he was very skilled at home repairs. He could build amazing things like bookshelves or cupboards.

My parents only moved house once, but my mother loved changing furniture. Just when you got used to one chair, another would appear. The biggest change was when a piano arrived. I wanted to like it, but it intimidated me. I did like the brass candlesticks on it, but my mother thought they were too fancy and removed them. I was never allowed to play the piano; my sister got lessons instead. When I asked my mother why I didn’t get the chance, she simply said, “You’d never have practiced.”

Given the choice between moors, woods, or river, I always chose the river. I loved to explore it with my imagination. I’d go with a fishing net and old sandals, looking for a spot to take off my shoes and try to catch fish. After failing to keep them alive at home, I’d release them back into the river.

I wanted to leave school as soon as possible, but it seemed unlikely until my father told me about an apprentice gardener job in the Parks Department. He thought I might be interested. Although he might have preferred me to become a carpenter, I like to think he believed things might work out if I pursued gardening. Even though he didn’t like gardening, he saw my passion for it and hoped it would lead to something good.

Lawrence MacEwen crouches down on the Isle of Muck, a small Scottish island. I do the same. A strong Atlantic wind threatens to blow us off the cliff and into the ocean below. MacEwen's sheepdog, Tie, comes over, and MacEwen gently pets him. Despite the fierce wind, MacEwen feels completely at home on his island. He points out the nearby islands to me. "That one is Eigg," he shouts over the wind. "To the west is the Isle of Rum, which gets twice as much rain as we do." I see heavy clouds pouring rain on Rum's mountains. "Beyond Rum is the island of Soay," he adds. Suddenly, MacEwen says he needs to move his sheep as rain approaches. We walk down the slopes, and he tells me about the island: Muck is volcanic, three kilometers long and half as wide. The geese eat a lot of grass, and the MacEwen family has lived here for 3000 years. As we herd the sheep, Tie, the sheepdog, struggles to control the flock. "Away to me, Tie," MacEwen instructs, meaning the dog should circle right. But Tie goes straight through the flock, causing chaos. "Tie," MacEwen says, disappointed. The dog looks ashamed. The Isle of Muck is mainly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence manages the farm with his wife, Jenny. Their son, Colin, takes care of the island cottages, and their daughter, Mary, runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby enjoy that their two boys can explore the island freely and sail small boats in the summer. "They leave the house and only come back when they're hungry," Mary says. However, island life has its challenges. Electricity is only available part-time. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to come on. The next morning, Mary prepares breakfast by torchlight. I adjust to this, along with having no mobile phone service. "There's reception on the hill," Mary tells me. "Most people give up after a couple of days and put their phones away." I do the same. Life on Muck feels wonderfully unusual. The boat today brings groceries and three musicians, who perform a concert in the island's tearoom. The islanders enjoy the music, tapping their boots in rhythm. That night, by a warm fire, Lawrence MacEwen tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. "Her father bought a small farm on the Isle of Soay from a newspaper ad, without seeing it. He'd never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it." Did Jenny know about farming? "She was good at typing," he laughs. I go to bed with the sound of rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, with almost all the food coming from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I bring it back to Mary, who cooks it for dinner. By 7 pm, the fish is on the table, and it tastes amazing. The next morning, I am supposed to take a ferry to another island. However, many ferries have been canceled recently due to rough seas. If my ferry doesn't come, I'll be stuck on Muck for two more days. Secretly, I hope it doesn't come, phone or no phone.

The game design industry used to be mainly for computer scientists and self-taught individuals, with few ways to enter it. It was often seen as just a hobby for young people, but now it's being taken seriously. Industry experts aren't surprised by this change. However, it's not easy to get into. Creating video game spin-offs for new movies requires many team members and months of hard work and skill. Like many industries, it's challenging to break into, but it is growing.

Jim Donelly, from an online games magazine, says it's tough to make progress in big companies or influence major games. But the industry needs game designers more than ever, not just leaders but also those who design systems and specific parts of games. So, how can you enter this competitive field? While many companies prefer a degree in computer science, Jim believes the key is to make games. The tools are available, and you need to create something to get a job or succeed independently. Game design is more a lifestyle than just a job. Like any creative work, it must be practiced to be real.

Another expert, John Field, agrees that just starting is important, but it's more complex than that. Many want to work in games, but few meet the industry's current demands. Even fewer have the creative talent, technical skills, vision, and business sense to contribute to this evolving field. Can you succeed on your own? "Maybe, but it's quite difficult," says John. A good postgraduate course in games can help, offering support and guidance. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all forms of entertainment and have a strong interest in arts and contemporary culture. They might have worked for a few years after graduation but realized games are their passion. They are not just fans but are excited about the future of games and understand the growing variety in the field. Networking is also important to get ahead in games, as in many other areas.

The old stereotype of a teenage boy playing video games has changed. Now, games are seen as a mature medium that captures our attention. Families often play together on interactive consoles. Smartphones offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is a lot of room for growth. Games have become popular with large audiences and are a great way to learn. He sees this already big area as full of possibilities and opportunities.

Since I was a child, all I wanted to do was play football. My dad encouraged me, but he didn't force me, and I'm thankful for that. I had a friend whose dad was very pushy, always telling him what he couldn't do. My friend could have been a good player, but he lost interest and stopped playing football. I'm glad that didn't happen to me, but I know it could have.

When I score an amazing goal from far away, people often say it's just luck, but it's not. I've practiced shooting from a distance since I was a kid. It's only through practice that you can score spectacular goals. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice for years. Sometimes young players crash into each other, but I was taught technique. When I teach kids, I focus on helping them enjoy learning skills.

I used to play every sport at school, from rounders and baseball to athletics and basketball. I know education is important, but back then, football was all I thought about. The teachers did a good job, but I didn't realize it at the time. I don't want it to be like that for my son. We try to read him books, even though he's too young to sit still. I hope his habit of kicking them around doesn't mean he's like me in that way.

At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so younger players like me could join the first team, but he didn't make a big deal about it. He didn't gather us and say, "This is your big chance," but we knew it was. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost, and a famous TV presenter said, "You can't win anything with kids." That made us realize how much we had to do. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team.

I rely a lot on close friends and family. Having a lot of money can cause problems. People sometimes say, "I can't believe you let your mother keep working." Of course, I've helped my parents financially. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family is strong and would be offended if they thought they should be on my payroll. My mum doesn't earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. I enjoy using my money to make life easier for those around me. I have a lot of money, though not as much as people think, but it doesn't solve everything.

After I stop playing, I plan to take a year off, maybe longer, to do things I haven't been able to do. I want to go skiing right after I stop playing. I can't do that now because if I broke a leg skiing and couldn't play football again, I wouldn't be insured.

Sam Carter was the reason we were living at Reef Point. He was my father's agent in Los Angeles. My father couldn't write anything sellable while we were in Los Angeles because he didn't like the city. Sam was worried about losing money and clients, so he found us a cheap place to live. During the summer, the beach was empty because sea fogs often covered the sun. Reef Point wasn't popular with day-trippers. The road to get there was not appealing, and the nearby resort of La Carmella was more attractive for those with some money. Only people who were broke or loved surfing would go the extra mile to Reef Point. But when the weather got hot, the place filled with people. After months of being almost alone, we were suddenly surrounded by activity. My father was busy trying to meet a writing deadline and was in a bad mood. Most days, I went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty, without him noticing. We didn't have a dog when we first moved to Reef Point, but Rusty decided to adopt us. I tried to chase him away, but he kept coming back. One morning, I felt sorry for him and gave him some water. My father half-heartedly threw a boot at him, but Rusty wasn't scared. I asked my father who Rusty might belong to, and he said, "You're wrong, Jane. He thinks we belong to him." Rusty loved the beach and often dug things up to bring to me. Sometimes, he brought things he hadn't dug up, like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel, which I had to return to their owners. Rusty also loved swimming and always joined me, even though I was faster. He never got discouraged. That day, my father had gone to Los Angeles to deliver his script, and Rusty and I spent the afternoon swimming. As the sun set, we watched the surfers. They had been surfing all day and seemed tireless. One surfer stood out with her graceful style. She decided to finish for the day and rode a final wave to the shore. She greeted me and asked why I hadn't joined them. I told her I didn't have a surfboard and no money to buy one. She noticed I was British and asked if I was visiting. I explained that I lived there because my father was writing a film script. She asked if she might know him, and I said his name was Rufus Marsh. She recognized the name from his novel, "Tall as the Morning," and looked at me with new interest. I realized people were friendly but only truly interested when I mentioned my father's book.

Violet Hetherington was standing in a long queue at the Southampton dock, waiting to board the Queen Caroline cruise ship. Her friend Annie, who often traveled, had advised her to arrive late to avoid waiting too long. However, this advice turned out to be wrong. An announcement over the loudspeakers said there was a problem with the computer system, which made the waiting passengers frustrated. They had paid a lot for this trip and expected better service.

Violet felt like leaving, especially when she realized she had lost her phone. This was more troubling than the long wait because all her important contacts were stored in it. Her son Harry had always warned her to avoid such mistakes. She asked a friendly couple behind her in the queue if she could use their phone. She called Harry and left a message, asking him to contact her neighbor Kristina to check if the phone was at her flat. If it wasn’t there, she would have trouble finding the numbers she needed in New York.

Finally, the queue started moving, and Violet handed over her travel documents to board the ship. Her heart sank when she saw the ship’s foyer, which looked like a hotel trying too hard to be fancy. There were fake walnut panels, shiny chandeliers, and carpets like those in airports. She took the elevator, which was crowded with tired passengers, to her room on the twelfth floor. Thankfully, her room had the balcony she had requested. She had paid extra to ensure she could see the sea, ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a last-minute deal.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he had no idea he was about to uncover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was searching for images for a book about the history of the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images by Maier, a street photographer with a talent for capturing striking images. Since then, Maloof has collected an archive of Maier’s life and work. In his attic studio, he has her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes. On a recent morning, Maloof stood among all these items, realizing he had stumbled upon something special by chance. ‘When I bought all this, I had no idea what it was,’ Maloof said. ‘I’m a third-generation flea market seller and could have easily just sold it all to someone else.’

For some time, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been piecing together the details of Maier’s life. They contacted local families who employed her as a nanny and spoke with employees of the shop where she developed her film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier, who was known to be private and a bit eccentric, always carried a camera. She wore oversized coats, broad-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. ‘First thing in the morning on her day off, the camera would be around her neck, and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,’ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. ‘I remember her as a private person but one who had very strong opinions about movies and politics.’

Maier was knowledgeable about theater and movies. Although she wasn’t very sociable, she wasn’t afraid to walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, some of whom she recorded on audiotape. She seemed to be passionate about her ‘second job’ of documenting the world around her. ‘She was a true artist and followed her dreams and what she wanted to do in life,’ said Rydzon. ‘She didn’t let anyone or anything stop her.’ Maier’s work is pure art; none of it was done for commercial reasons. Her images often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract subjects. ‘What is intriguing about Vivian is that there are so many interesting pictures,’ said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees the influence of many other photographers in her pictures and wonders if she developed her own style independently. ‘Was Vivian very sophisticated and able to do this, or did she borrow ideas from those who came before her?’

Maloof often wonders if he’ll ever go through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof file cabinets. Interestingly, he had no real interest in photography until he discovered Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural shots, Maloof started taking his own pictures. ‘As I progressed as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized the cityscapes were not what was important to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, the overall composition,’ he said. ‘There was so much more to this work than I thought, and I realized that I was sitting on something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to get her name out there. To get Vivian Maier into the history books.'

When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it didn't fully succeed. However, this isn't true for Eleanor Catton's book, *The Luminaries*. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very popular, and she was calm, even though she was still in her twenties. She had just come from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She showed her novel to the officer, who then asked, "What's it about?" This is a tough question for any author. 

*The Luminaries* is set in New Zealand during the 1860s. It involves a series of crimes and a group of 12 men trying to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton said she wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found that the past allowed for more complications and misunderstandings for her characters. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters enough attention.

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she replied modestly. She said it's nice coming from a small country because everyone shares in the success. She received a lot of support from people back home. She also mentioned that it bothers her when people don't see her book as a philosophical work. 

Catton had the idea to write the book in the shape of a spiral, with each part being half the length of the previous one. This makes the story feel like it speeds up. I asked if it matters whether readers notice this. She said she wanted to create a book with hidden patterns that readers could explore if they wanted to. Despite its experimental structure, *The Luminaries* is still an exciting murder mystery with a gripping plot. Surprisingly, she didn't plan the story in advance. She would write herself into difficult situations and then find creative ways to resolve them. 

One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers. We also talked about her love for TV drama series. Considering how *The Luminaries* uses cliff-hangers, different viewpoints, and dialogue, I asked if she might be interested in screenwriting. She said that could be interesting. Her conversation was lively and full of enthusiasm, especially when talking about her writing and New Zealand. She mentioned how her imagination changes when she visits different places, like Britain. She understands why some writers leave New Zealand for busier places to be around more people. But for now, she plans to stay in New Zealand, and many hope it continues to inspire her future novels.

When Jonny Kinkead was a boy, he loved using tools in his dad’s garage and playing the guitar. These hobbies became his career for the last forty years: making steel-string acoustic guitars by hand. Jonny says, "I’m still amazed by the guitar. How can two pieces of wood make such a beautiful sound? And using different types of wood changes the sound. It still amazes me."

Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar at eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. "Some people would get a job and save money to buy one," he says. "But I thought if you wanted something, you made it yourself. I studied guitars to understand how different shapes and woods affected the sound and how to build them." The bass was the first instrument Jonny made from scratch, but he and his brothers had been making other things for a long time. "We designed and built model boats and planes, so I knew the process. My father taught us how to use tools. I also fixed and customized instruments for my friends."

Jonny’s bass guitar was a success, but he didn’t think about making guitars as a career. "I was also interested in painting and sculpture," he says. After finishing school, he chose to study architecture at university. "Architecture involves design, which I liked, and being an architect seemed like a good idea," he remembers. But halfway through, he left the course. "I was too independent for it," he says. "But I realized what I wanted to do. I was still interested in sculpture, but I saw that making guitars is like sculpting sound. It seemed more practical than pure art because you make things people use."

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time. At first, he sold guitars for just the cost of materials, but as he became known as a top guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is "still just getting by." He admits he can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income. In the early years, he worked hard to get noticed. He went to music festivals most weekends to let musicians try his guitars and spread the word. He also had to learn how to price his guitars, which was difficult for him.

Jonny thinks it’s easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. "When I started, people thought the best acoustic guitars were made in the USA," he says. "UK-made guitars weren’t seen as good, even though we’ve always had good courses and skills here. But now, our hand-made guitars have the reputation they deserve." Jonny says valuable skills can be learned in classes, and he encourages new instrument-makers to take courses. However, he also believes there’s no substitute for trial and error. "Look at other instruments, see what works or doesn’t, and try different things," Jonny says. "If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If someone else teaches you, you learn one way, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything."

Any talk about English conversation usually starts with the weather. This is a common tradition, and many writers mention the famous quote by Dr. Johnson, an eighteenth-century diarist, who said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This statement is still true today. However, many people who write about this topic either stop here or try to explain why English people seem so interested in the weather, but they often fail. They fail because they think that when English people talk about the weather, they are actually interested in it. For example, the American writer Bill Bryson notes that English weather is not very exciting, lacking extreme events like tornadoes or blizzards, and finds the English interest in it puzzling. On the other hand, English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman argues that the weather is interesting because it is unpredictable. He says that living near the ocean and a continent means you can never be sure what the weather will be like.

My research shows that both Bryson and Paxman miss the real point. English people don't talk about the weather because they care about it; instead, it's a way to start conversations and connect with others. Phrases like "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" are not really about the weather. They are like greetings or ways to fill gaps in conversation. This is similar to how monkeys and apes groom each other to bond socially. There are specific times when English people use weather-talk: as a greeting, to break the ice and start a conversation, or as a topic when there is nothing else to say. This happens often enough that it seems like English people talk about the weather all the time. An English conversation might start with a weather-related greeting, use more weather-talk to keep the conversation going, and return to it if there is a pause. This is why people from other countries, and even some English writers, think that English people are obsessed with the weather.

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how impressive it was for the Romans to build a wall 120 km long and 5 meters high nearly 1900 years ago.
