The students were already interested because they chose this trip over more glamorous ones to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they were curious about why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not satisfying. When she couldn't find a historical novel to give more context and interest to life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After retiring from teaching in 2001, Alice started a new career as an author. She felt it was a big change from her successful teaching career. ‘Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very demanding. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but it’s not as tiring. My old teaching colleagues are jealous because I still connect with children through my stories.’ Alice wants her novels to fill a gap in children’s fiction today. ‘Many books for teenagers now focus on negative experiences. They are well written,’ she adds, ‘but many are dark or completely fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are different.’ Alice always taught English and History together, like teaching about ancient Greece with the novel Tale of Troy, and she loves seeing children go from bored to interested. ‘I love when bored children become interested. It’s up to me to make that happen.’ She sees writing as an extension of teaching. She was inspired to write her first novel because there was a gap in the market and because her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher also suggested she try a creative writing course. Alice was surprised. ‘I’d been teaching for 25 years. She said it would be good for me. But I didn’t want to spend my summer holiday on a course I didn’t think I needed.’ Before the course, she had to send her best piece of fiction, which she found out just days before leaving. ‘I sat at the computer and created a story about a Roman couple and their baby.’ Three hours and 30 pages later, she sent it in and was accepted. During the course, other students reviewed her work and suggested she publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked her school’s head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, a critic and editor, helped her edit the novel. Alice says, ‘My mother-in-law thinks we’re rival authors, but I think we complement each other. He works with what I’ve written – he reads a chapter and changes the sentence structure, and if it’s not working, he suggests different words. My instinct is to keep adding scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor or critic.’

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to compete in a special race. The race would be between a man and a car, and also between the two brothers. In the wild and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny would drive a car on the roads, while his younger brother Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. 

"I'm excited about it," Jonny said at the start line. "I've never done anything like this before. The roads have beautiful views, and it's very cold right now, so I'll be warm in the car." Alistair was also eager, but unlike Jonny, who wore jeans and a sweatshirt, he was dressed in full winter cycling gear. The cold didn't bother him. "Honestly," he said, "I've seen Jonny drive before, so I'm not sure he'll even make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up."

The race began at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and was to end at Yorkshire's highest road, Fleet Moss, which is 350 meters up. This might not be a problem for the car, but Alistair's first few miles included a steep 25 percent incline, making it tough from the start. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair sped away on his bike, heading up a hill and across the countryside to Fleet Moss, while Jonny got into the car and hit the road. The next time they would see each other would be at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first?

Jonny's early confidence was quickly challenged. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he encountered his first obstacle: a giant tractor moving onto the road. "Welcome to Yorkshire," he joked to the cameraman in his car. "If Alistair beats me, it's because of this farmer!" After dealing with the tractor, Jonny was back on track, driving into the morning mist.

Meanwhile, Alistair was struggling with the steep slope. Just a couple of miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched curiously as the Olympic champion kept a steady pace, carrying his bike. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side was open ground, and with the sun coming out, he had a chance to show his skills. He picked up speed, head down, feet on the pedals.

In the car, Jonny faced another local challenge. The villages in this part of Yorkshire have been around since before cars were invented, and the roads are not built for speed. Jonny carefully navigated a very narrow corner and drove through a stream on the road. Once past the last village, he raced straight to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped through the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the other side. Head down, legs pumping, he reached the line and stopped. 

Alistair looked up and asked the crowd, "Is he here?" When they said no, he raised his arms in victory. Minutes later, Jonny arrived in the car. "Well done," Jonny said, clearly disappointed. "I'm gutted."

Playing on Centre Court at Wimbledon is a unique experience because of the silence. When you bounce the ball on the soft grass, you hear only the sound of your own shots. The well-kept grass, the historic stadium, the players in white, and the respectful audience create a special atmosphere that feels separate from the outside world. This quiet helps me focus on my game. During a match, I try to block out everything except the game and the point I'm playing. The silence is only broken by applause and cheers when a point is won. Even though there are 15,000 people watching in the stadium and millions more on TV, I am so focused that I hardly notice them. 

In 2008, I played Roger Federer in the Wimbledon final, the biggest match of my life. I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach forever, taught me that Wimbledon is the most important tournament. By age 14, I was already telling my friends that I would play and win there one day. Before 2008, I had played and lost twice to Federer in the finals. The 2006 loss wasn't too hard because I was just happy to have reached the final at age 20. But the 2007 loss was devastating because I knew I could have done better. It wasn't my skills that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing is always painful, but it's worse when you know you had a chance to win. 

Toni, who is usually very tough on me, tried to comfort me after that loss, saying there would be more chances. I told him he didn't understand, that it might have been my last chance to win. I know a professional athlete's career is short, and I want to make the most of it. Some moments are more important than others, and I felt I had missed a big one in 2007. But Toni was right; I got another chance in 2008. I was confident I had learned from my previous defeat and that my mindset would be strong this time. The night before the final, I had dinner with family and friends, but we didn't talk about the match. They knew I was already mentally preparing for it, and I needed that space to be mine alone until the match started.

In April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. 

In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society helped make Jane famous by creating articles and TV documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including children's books and the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," which has been translated into 47 languages. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, possibly second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements. Many stories about her life focus on her adventurous spirit or her role as a feminist, but these can undervalue her true contributions.

Jane Goodall's work is highly respected in the scientific community. Her research has been widely referenced, and many of her students have become influential scientists. Her forty-year study of chimpanzees has provided a vast amount of data. She is considered a pioneer in her field and the world's leading zoologist. Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew they ate meat or used tools, and we didn't realize they had emotions similar to ours or complex social systems. We also didn't know that chimpanzee communities have different cultural traditions.

Jane's book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her long-term study in Gombe, Nigeria, is seen as one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and, because chimpanzees are our closest relatives, she also changed how we think about ourselves.

Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. When she was five, she disappeared one afternoon, causing a search by police and neighbors. She reappeared with straw in her hair, explaining that she had hidden in a henhouse for five hours to see how hens lay eggs. This curiosity and patience hinted at her future as a biologist.

Shirley Ford is a voiceover artist who can speak in many different voices. During our first conversation, she used the voice of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV, cartoons, and even some workplace training videos. Recently, she did a voiceover about back injuries, which required her to quickly learn medical terms.

Shirley explains that doing voiceovers is more than just making funny voices. Many well-known actors want to do voiceover work, but they often don't get the roles because they are used to acting with their whole bodies, not just their voices. After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning to become a traditional actor. She occasionally sang jingles for TV ads, and one day, she was asked to try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. Although it seemed silly, she got a major role, which led her to realize her talent for voiceovers.

In her second film, Shirley voiced the main character, her brother, and her mother. Female actors often voice young boys and girls because their voices are lighter, and hiring child actors involves complicated procedures that production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create different child voices by watching children’s TV and practicing.

Her work includes a variety of projects, from educational videos to vacuum cleaner ads. She finds it challenging to sound enthusiastic about things she doesn't care about, but smiling while talking helps make her voice sound cheerful. Animation work is her favorite because interacting with other actors feels like a holiday.

The competition in voiceover work is tough, and having a good showreel is crucial. Shirley advises investing in a strong showreel and suggests attending specialist workshops for those interested in voiceover careers. She believes that a passion for voices is essential and describes herself as obsessed with them. Sometimes, after working in a particular voice, she continues speaking that way for hours or even days. Her children are used to hearing her speak in different voices.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a job many dream about as kids, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more practical careers, like becoming a tax lawyer or working in auto parts manufacturing. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like those in school notebooks, seems silly. Yet, some people do just that. 

People don't all become cartoonists in the same way, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. In my case, I had a typical cartoonist's childhood: I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons on local issues. I created some ideas, they bought them, and within a few months, I was earning enough to support myself.

To become a cartoonist, you don't need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical skills needed are basic, but it's still a challenging job. You shouldn't try to become a cartoonist unless you feel you can't do anything else. It's easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and leaves time for family and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I've done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I've also been a writer, caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don't refuse any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don't really want to do. It also helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But those days are mostly over. Today, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to create the work and sell it. The better you are at this, the more successful you'll be. I've seen cartoonists with average talent but great business skills do better than artistic geniuses who lack those skills.

It's surprising how many people are afraid someone will steal their ideas, even if they've never sold a cartoon. Some are so worried they won't let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small 'c' for 'copyright,' put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But honestly, it's more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it goes viral online, it might actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and decided to get rid of some things. One of those things was an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate throwing things away, so why did I want to get rid of it? I took it to the dump and was about to throw it away when a young man approached me, looking confused. He asked, "Are you really going to throw that away?" I said yes, already feeling a bit of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I agreed. We went our separate ways, but I felt sad about it for years.

Then, a few months ago, I got an email that changed everything. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later inside a fish. The email was from a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He told me, "I have your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so emotional; I would have paid anything, but his price was fair. I had forgotten my dad's habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have found this whole situation funny!

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar in the 1970s when it was very popular. I loved its calming sound, but I didn't make much progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn't need to be a great musician to be a rock star. When I got my guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I felt the urge to stand up and play it with a strap over my shoulder. My fingers remembered the chords, even though I couldn't draw them. My fingertips felt the familiar pain of pressing the strings.

The electric guitar isn't really for playing alone, so now that I'm learning it again, I might need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe there are others my age with similar stories. We could call ourselves "The Regainers"!

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," which is about people who can't sleep well, I felt like I was the only one talking about how dangerous it is to not get enough sleep. Lack of sleep affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who struggle with sleep know how important it is for our mental, physical, and social health. It's good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them in these discussions. We often lose dreams when we wake up early, missing the last hour or two of sleep. This is usually REM sleep, which is when we dream the most. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen during REM sleep, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years dreaming. When researchers stop people from having REM sleep, they have more intense REM sleep the next night to make up for it. This suggests that dreams are important. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who thought that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research did not fully support this idea. The study of dreams shifted to focus more on their physical origins rather than psychological ones. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, says Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than other people. He concluded that people who are interested in creativity use their dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Doesn't everyone—like teachers, software designers, and politicians—need to think creatively? According to Stickgold, dreams help us combine things in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new connections. Dreams might help us see new patterns and create ideas that break our usual way of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken up from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They ignore the obvious and connect things in unexpected ways. This is what creativity is, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, or one you can barely remember, seems to help with thinking. On those days, words and images come so quickly that my fingers can hardly keep up. I don't know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn't just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and we all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, co-workers, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England twenty years ago. In her studio, which has a beautiful view of the sea, there are empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leading figure in the copyist art movement, known for her ability to recreate famous paintings from artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that even art experts can mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings are worth millions, Susie's copies sell for between a few hundred pounds and £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them.

Susie has many clients, including galleries and private collectors, but she keeps their names private. Some collectors buy her copies to show off, while others use them to save on insurance by keeping the original in a safe. Susie is honest about her work and always signs her name on the back of the canvas. She believes that making a poor copy would disrespect the original artist. Although some people sell copies as originals, which is illegal, Susie avoids this because it could damage her reputation.

Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. This job taught her to be precise and accurate, skills that are important in her current work. She advises young artists to learn to draw well and to study hard. Susie specializes in French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. She explains that while impressionist art looks simple, it requires great attention to detail.

Despite her talent, Susie doesn't create her own original art. She has tried, but her attempts, like oil paintings of fishing nets, ended up looking like photographs. She is a perfectionist and finds satisfaction in her work as a copyist, which provides her with a good living.

During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur was deeply passionate about the sea and being the fastest sailor. From a young age, she was obsessed with sailing. She felt a strong connection with the boats she sailed around the world, working in perfect harmony with them. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and she quickly longed to be back at sea, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop race around the world, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was a small, cramped space where she lived and worked for 94 days. She explained how she meticulously planned everything, down to the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly displayed her supplies of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies and rations. Her attention to detail in maintaining the boat was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her entire world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. This experience made her think differently and realize things she hadn't considered before. Seeing abandoned whaling stations felt like a warning about how humans take what they want and move on.

When I met Ellen at her office, she had just finished an intense conference call. She explained why urgent action is needed to save the planet. "No one is making more coal, oil, or gas. These are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways not to use them up," she said. Initially, her message was about using less, but she later realized the importance of reusing. She passionately talks about things like reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, Ellen has visited factories, mines, and power stations, speaking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she says, "but I love learning. The current situation became something I couldn't ignore. Sailing seemed selfish in comparison. This is about finding how my voice can be most useful. It really matters."

Ellen also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to inspire young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she says. "It defines who I am. At sea, you are connected to everything around you, focused on records, practicalities, and survival. My new message isn't as simple as saying, 'I’m going to be the fastest person around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I've ever done."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous among teenagers. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan hopes to encourage them to go outside and try new challenges. His climbing team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is just one part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.

I talked to some experienced Everest climbers, and none of them thought it was a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world's highest mountain. They agreed that a young climber might be physically strong enough, but they were unsure if a teenager would be emotionally ready. They also doubted that a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing. The Romeros have heard these concerns before. Paul says, 'I know people criticize us, but I can't focus on that – there's still a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we trust our experience as climbers. Watching Jordan grow stronger gives me confidence.'

I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it just his father's ambition? Paul insists, 'This isn't about me wanting fame through my son. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later in life, but we decided, why not now? We regularly check with him to make sure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on achieving my goal.'

In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting challenge. The more exciting the record, the more interest it gets. This creates a challenge for Jordan. People might say that focusing on records takes away from the enjoyment, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something impressive, like climbing Everest. Paul adds, 'If Jordan decides tomorrow that he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we'll end this project and head to the gym.'

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's likely they aren't listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I'm studying music at university, but even my classmates don't know much about classical music. If you don't know the composers, you probably don't own their music. The statistics for classical music are discouraging. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells only 300 copies. I find this surprising. Why has interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries, declined? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn't attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. Some teenagers do attend classical concerts, but they are few. Although I play in an orchestra, I'm not a big fan of classical music. I enjoy many styles, but my classical music collection is probably around that 3% mark. Why don't teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm, with many mood changes, are challenging for us. We like things fast. Experts say we struggle to focus for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop songs also have lyrics that appeal more to teenagers than long classical pieces without words. The way we listen to music has changed. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, we can find any music online, but we rarely choose classical. When was the last time you heard classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says classical concert audiences have grown recently. Maybe, but I doubt many teenagers are in those audiences. In my orchestra, we play classical music in various places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don't know why more people go to classical concerts as they get older, but I do know that if teenagers' parents love something, they often avoid it. Some blame schools for teenagers' lack of interest in classical music, but many kids are eager to play in school orchestras. They practice early and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy performing classical music, but it's not their first choice for listening. When we relax, we usually choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you regret that I’m here," she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the car too and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie wouldn’t have minded if she had. Her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a wooded hillside; it was confusing at first. Then she saw the signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," Bonnie said, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother said. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved between trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t seem to expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be kicked out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and headed for the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building where the horses were kept and a large area for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. Bonnie treated horses well. The horses were well cared for, she could see that right away. Almost every stall was full, and she walked along, looking at each horse and judging it. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony as she touched its nose. The next horse surprised her. "But aren’t you the best of the lot!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. Probably lively, but Bonnie liked that. "You know, I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "It was in my dreams, and I was riding you to win a big competition…" His name was above the stall: Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you. They can’t be far." The room with all the riding equipment was – to Bonnie’s delight – unlocked. Absorbed in the fun task of putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat high on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in charge of everything she could see. Her nickname at her previous school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said admiringly, "and I’m not joking, because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She nudged him into a walk, then a trot. "If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends," she confided. She went around the paddock. The rhythm was exciting, a little breeze brushing her cheek and making it glow. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he’d jump well.

I’ve met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. Cody is a 15-year-old Australian who has already released several successful songs. How did a relaxed surfer end up performing on stage for thousands of fans? Cody explains, "I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven." He remembers how it all started. "But I was swimming every day and surfing. Those were more important to me back then; I had my life planned and lots to do. I was 13, going to high school, and then I posted a few videos online." These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of him and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos on their social media. So Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The responses were overwhelming. Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with top coaches, focusing on his sport. But then record labels showed interest, and he had a tough choice: stay in Australia and continue swimming, or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the risk. "It was very hard for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career. Can you imagine, at 12 or 13, trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?" He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. "It was a big surprise to most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid," he says, remembering their shocked reactions. "I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to be that way in this crazy world." So Cody packed his bags and moved with his family halfway around the world, giving up one dream to try to make another come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn’t directly involved in his career, they support him from the background. Cody says it’s important to have a close group of great people around you to keep you grounded. Of course, we all have days of doubt. "Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight, and he’s traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a regular life," Cody admits. "I worry about that sometimes, but my family always reassures me that they’re here to support and encourage me in everything I do." Success, in any career, comes from being willing to say "yes" to your big opportunity, even when it’s a bit scary. "It all happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, to be visiting countries I never thought I’d see and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s like something many people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won’t last forever."

I jumped out of bed, pulled back the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbag wall, which was there to stop the buildings from flooding when the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting those sandbags into place. Last week, I worked with most of the town's adults for long hours, showing I could handle it. But my grandfather didn't seem to notice. With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of steaming black water from the wood factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on both sides, and solid ice downstream. As I took off my pajamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. I didn't recognize him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky chain I keep there—a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. It's better than having a famous grandfather because only he, my mom, and I know about it. Plus, I have his diary from that trip. I keep it under my pillow and read it before I sleep. I patted the chain and went to the kitchen. "Morning, Rex," Mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. "You're up early for a Saturday. I'll make brunch after your training. Be careful." "Thanks, Mom." I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa as he came out of his room. "Watch where you're going," he shouted. "Where are you going?" "Sorry, Grandpa. I'm going kayaking." As if my wetsuit didn't make that clear. As if he didn't see me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it's getting harder. "Why train? You didn't win the competition," he said. His words stung, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He went into the bathroom and slammed the door. Mom gave me a sympathetic smile. "Don't mind him. He's..." "...not himself right now," I finished for her. I didn't say he's always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a kid, he was my hero—from the time he showed me his photos in National Geographic. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don't go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe soon, my own face in National Geographic. Yet, a part of me still wants to be loyal to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. "At least he's coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination, even on cold days!" I smiled back as I peeled my banana. "It'll be warmer in South America," I said. "If I find sponsors for my expedition." She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. I hurried to the boathouse in the backyard.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly Grandpa's work, but it looked different from anything he had done before and was obviously unfinished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. It showed a river that took up most of the scene. It wasn't a river she recognized and might not even be real, maybe just imaginary. The picture was strange and shapeless, yet beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely noticeable, just a hint of green that the eye almost missed, as it was drawn into the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice—too casual, too detached—that showed her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others figure them out, if they could. Mum turned the picture over and pointed to the words Grandpa had scribbled there. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed to have a special meaning, as if they were important to her, but she didn't know why. And there was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it—for him to be so specific. Still, he hasn't finished it yet, so maybe he's going to add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual picture, especially having a name. I guess you can imagine his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not the artist's job to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to waste time telling every idiot..." "Ignoramus, he said." "...every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone who came along, they'd never get any work done. And he said..." Mum interrupted her, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting, since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually, it was just to say the muse wasn't being kind to him that day, or that he'd have to be nice to the muse because he had a difficult part to work on, or something like that. He never suggested the muse had anything to do with her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a human being. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, having any influence over someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally cut the carpet. I'm not saying that's what happened, just that it could have. I didn't wake up thinking, "Today I'll cut a hole in my carpet." It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm quite unlucky that way.

What I was actually trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's really cute! It's small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and has tiny glass-panelled doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet, so I was very excited when she gave it to me! But it's a corner cabinet, which means it has to stand in a corner. It's shaped like a triangle for that reason.

I only have two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. But since Angela is only fifteen, it seems I'll be in my small room for a while. I don't really mind; I like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could only take a couple of centimetres off the bottom...

That's when I had the idea. If I couldn't cut anything off Gran's cabinet, maybe I could cut a hole in the carpet. It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to "think outside the box." And that's exactly what I was doing!

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in a house. They secretly take things from the normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be difficult to meet fans' expectations. People who love the book have strong opinions about how it should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' point of view, not the humans', which made filming more complicated. The most important thing was getting the size difference right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when filming them, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. To show the Borrowers' view of the human world, the crew had to film from no higher than 15 centimeters off the ground, which wore out a lot of jeans! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. A big challenge was making the shadows look right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous US director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry giant items like scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh. In the story, there's a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses, and they said it was so scary they didn't have to act. Getting the costumes right was important to me, and other directors have struggled with this in other versions. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls' clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn't sit during breaks and had to be sewn into the dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, it was really hot during filming, and I don't think they appreciated my attention to detail! Most scenes away from the Borrowers' home were filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen. It was challenging for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each should look – I did 2,000 by the end. They weren't accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn't allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once filmed a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists who aren't there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the people pretending to be friends, and the ones asking for free tickets to my dad's concerts. "Everything's going to be fine," I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me to face this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to leave my old life of traveling and tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we're staying permanently. I chose this school because I want to meet real kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so normal. 

I walk into the school's main office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I say to the school secretary. "Name?" she asks, not looking very friendly. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she asks, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. She seems confused but types "McGraw" on her keyboard. That's one good thing—few people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it's printing," she says, then hands me the schedule. English Literature is my first class. Great, I like English. I'll be late, though. English is in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn't look lost. When I reach the door, the teacher is already calling roll. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. Perfect, no one will suspect anything! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew they were too flashy. "Thanks," I say. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she asks. "Here." The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After discussing the books we'll read this year, she lets us socialize. All teachers should do this. "So why'd you move here?" my new friend asks. I have many options. Do I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else choose a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. Yes, lies work better. "What does he do?" she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out eventually. But at least I can pretend to be normal for a while. "He's an artist," I say, playing with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I'm Becca, by the way." And she doesn't seem to care. Perfect.

The average American teenage girl today is expected to do a lot. She should be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is what it means to be a teenager in America now. Teenagers can't just go to school and be average; they need to stand out. Being average is not enough, and not having big ambitions is seen as being lazy. 

Teenager Kristen Loose explains that people, especially adults, often forget how much pressure teenagers face today. They have lots of homework, tests, extra activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life. Despite these pressures, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist, often spread by the media. These stereotypes include being lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers might fit these descriptions, it's not fair to label the whole generation this way.

Loose points out that many people think teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or on their phones. She disagrees, saying that while she keeps her phone close, it's not just for fun. It's a tool that helps teenagers manage their busy lives. Today, students are expected to have instant access to information and be reachable at all times, which can look like a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can work anywhere, even doing homework on the go. Schoolwork and activities now demand attention around the clock, adding to the stress of already busy teens.

Many teenagers start their day at 6 or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight, filled with school, activities, family duties, and homework. They often get less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. A survey by the US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20% of teens get enough sleep, and 28% admitted to falling asleep in school at least once a week due to lack of sleep.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time a week, which isn't much out of 168 hours. She doesn't waste this time on social media or TV but focuses on volunteering. Olsen believes the stereotype of teenagers is that they only care about themselves, but she enjoys helping others and making a positive impact in her community.

In the future, the stereotype of teenagers might change, but they will continue to challenge it and push the world forward. A new generation of students will keep making a difference, even before they finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live near Bishop, a small town in the US surrounded by wilderness, east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. Over the past few years, this group has launched more than fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a long-term science project with a twist: it's part astronomy experiment, part adventure, which attracts teenagers. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. These stars appear when a rock or metal piece from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As night falls, the teenagers attach a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside, there's a camera, an altitude-measuring instrument, and a thermometer to track temperature changes. Two GPS trackers are on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by someone from a nearby state, inflates the balloon until it's as big as a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get the gas. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he says. For these kids, that's normal. Finally, it's time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chant, and the balloon rises. Some run and track it with flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There's a quiet, shared sense of wonder. Then the balloon vanishes into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets on the mountainside, looking at a sky so clear, it's hard to believe you're just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I see a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ says one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispers another. A meteor streaks across the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon expands until it's almost as big as a house. Then it bursts in a dramatic explosion. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely back on Earth. The students will find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Getting it back isn't easy, but that's part of the fun. There's little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ says the group’s leader, noting they've lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn't.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To reach it, the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or a tall tree. ‘It's important to remember that these students are from the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader says. ‘What seems wild and dangerous to some is just normal life to others.’ In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, high on a flat rock, in the middle of a waterfall. The camera didn't record any shooting stars. It's a bit disappointing, but it's also a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they work over mountains. And it's another adventure story to share with others.

Chloe Morgan admits that she wasn't interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she was fifteen. Her interest started by accident. Her younger brother was fascinated by dinosaurs, a common phase for kids, which she had ignored. She helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries in Palaeontology. It amazed her, and she realized she wanted to pursue it.

I asked her about the support she received since Palaeontology wasn't a typical career choice for young people then. She recalls meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous despite being young. She was nervous, fearing he might find her annoying with her questions. However, he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.

I mentioned how palaeontologists are shown in movies and TV shows. Chloe admits that films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs, but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She finds the portrayal of palaeontologists in films misleading, often showing them as either eccentric geniuses or awkward geeks. These films don't accurately show their daily work.

Chloe explains that her job is varied. She spends time digging up dinosaur bones, working in labs analyzing fossils, and writing for scientific journals. Although not a daily task, she also communicates scientific findings to the public. She believes it's important to address misunderstandings about science and enjoys reaching out to young people to inspire them about the natural world and science.

The TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs was a chance for Chloe to influence how dinosaurs are shown on screen. She praises the program makers for their knowledge and says she only needed to offer advice occasionally, like ensuring dinosaurs shown lived in the same time period. The program attracted audiences of all ages because it depicted dinosaurs more accurately than movies like Jurassic Park.

I asked why dinosaurs continue to fascinate us and remain a research focus. Chloe thinks they appeal to our inner explorer. They spark our imagination and remind us that there is still much to discover, making Palaeontology a form of time travel.

I'm going to say this just once: when you're on a car trip with your family, even if you're six years old, you probably know you're not "there yet," even if you keep asking, "Are we there yet?" And really, once you arrive, it's not "there" anymore; it's "here." So, if you think you might be "there," you should ask, "Are we here yet?" And no one wants to be "there" more than the parents who have to answer that question repeatedly during long car trips. Seriously, what are we kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing expected of you? You can watch DVDs you haven't seen, listen to music, or do puzzles you've had for a while, while the scenery passes by outside the window. In the front seat, there's mom or dad, who hands out juice boxes and cookies, changes the radio station, and adjusts the temperature—basically, they make sure everything goes smoothly. Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying—like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. What? He can't do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then it's his other foot, then a hand, and soon he's in my space, and we're fighting. The driver and co-pilot have to separate us as the car speeds up and swerves. They tell the younger sibling to stay in his seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a while. The beautiful scenery continues to pass by. Soon after, I'm trying to read, and I feel a breeze on my arm. But the car isn't going fast, and the window isn't open. Where's it coming from? My brother is in the next seat, quietly blowing air on me. He's on his side, not touching me, so he's technically not doing anything wrong. Just breathing? What's the problem with that? The anger builds. Tim gets yelled at, and there's more swerving. Then things calm down again—for now. Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle us kids in the back seat. For example, when we ask, "Are we there yet?" he often says, "Yes. We're here. Get out of the car." "But Dad, we're still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour." "Oh, well, then maybe we're not there yet." That keeps us quiet for a while. You know you're finally "there" when the adults get out of the car and move as far away as they can from the kids who have bothered them for hours. So remember: if mom and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no, you're not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope customers will love the experience and return. Zuzi explains their motivation: "With so much technology, everyone is busy on their phones. We wanted to bring people together without screens. It's natural for us to connect and communicate."

The games in their café are called 'Eurogames.' These games have gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements and trade resources, keeping everyone involved until the end. This idea was improved in 'co-operative' games, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction.

One popular Eurogame is Pandemic, created by North American designer Matt Leacock. In Pandemic, players work together to solve global problems. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. He recalls playing it with friends and feeling scared but excited, wanting to create a similar experience.

Leacock's love for board games started in childhood. He often felt disappointed with games, so with his uncle's help, he began designing better ones. Pandemic became very successful, and its sequel added more storytelling, similar to video games where characters develop and rules change.

Interestingly, the growth of video games has helped board games become popular. Video games have made playing games normal for many people. Ben Hogg, from a leading games company, says, "Everyone with a smartphone plays at least one game. More people are open to playing games now."

Video games once offered social interaction in arcades or with friends at home. But as online multiplayer games grew, players became physically distant. Some people missed playing games with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just fun. In our online world, these games offer a way to connect in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many setbacks. Jamie's mother was a great singer and taught him to play the guitar. Growing up, he only listened to a local radio station for middle-aged people, which influenced his musical taste. He didn't hear a modern song until he was 12. Around that time, he had to choose between playing tennis at a national level and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room, playing the piano. Although he was good at tennis, he realized it wasn't what he wanted to do for the rest of his life because it was too much hard work.

At 17, Jamie left school to pursue a career in music. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as passionate about a music career. Jamie told his parents he wanted to be a musician, explaining that he wrote lyrics during economics lessons and played the piano while others played outside. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels only wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend.

Jamie found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he switched to another label to release a new album, but fame and fortune didn't come. He felt that in his artist career, he was often in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as a writer, he was in the right place. Writing for others became his strength. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK, helping new artists start their careers. Sometimes he explains to artists that aiming for chart success is not something to be ashamed of. He asks them, "Don't you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?" He believes in writing songs that are both amazing and likely to sell well.

Jamie is straightforward about wanting to write hit songs that reach number one. He doesn't come across as arrogant; he simply knows he has a talent for writing hits. Instead of worrying about what others think, he focuses on his goal. When he works in the studio, he aims to create music that is globally successful and the best of the next year. It's not just about being trendy; he wants to write classic modern pop songs.

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very famous online but might be unknown to people who don't watch videos of bike stunts. He is a 'street trials cyclist,' which means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online. 

When I met him for an interview at a BMX park on a Saturday morning, many local boys recognized him immediately. Even older people came to show their admiration, calling him a 'legend.' After seeing his skills, I agreed with them. I was impressed by his bravery and creativity, even though I was skeptical at first. Before each stunt, he explained what he planned to do, and I often doubted he could succeed. But he always did, and when I praised him, he seemed uninterested and a bit down. 

Despite his online fame, Tony doesn't enjoy being a celebrity. He finds it hard to interact socially and prefers doing things rather than talking about them. This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and the technology that allows him to share his videos. He acknowledges that this technology helps him make a living, but he feels uncomfortable with how much people focus on screens and cameras. 

Tony earns a good income from his videos, which would have been just a hobby in the past. From my experience interviewing top athletes, I know that two key factors make a child become an elite athlete: energy and the ability to overcome disappointment. These are often more important than talent and help athletes keep going despite failures. In risky sports, mental strength is crucial. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on obstacles that were easy for him but new. He simply got up and tried again until he succeeded.

Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some think he is reckless and takes unnecessary risks. Tony responds that these critics don't understand the sport and have probably never ridden a trials bike. They don't know the technical details or that he gets expert advice to minimize risks. Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He believes it's important to be aware of dangers. Some people never feel scared, but Tony feels fear and finds a way to overcome it. He is not addicted to risk and spends a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes he needs to ride around to get in the right mindset before trying a new stunt. He knows he must stay calm and fully commit to the jump to succeed.

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on many dangerous challenges for charity. She has run a marathon in the desert and traveled down the Amazon River in a small boat. Her latest challenge was walking on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground. She walked between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, just a belt around her waist connected to another wire above her. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. Helen learned from an expert high-wire walker. Even though she had some circus skills, she found high-wire walking to be very different. "The training was a shock," Helen said. "I didn’t know how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and another hour after practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could continue. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I got nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!" On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. "That was the scariest thing I’ve done," she said afterward. "I’m glad it’s over!" Despite this, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole using skis, a kite, and a bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, which is an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. Before this, he had written a book about traveling around Canada in a 50-year-old car. He loved motor sports and worked on building racing car engines. To save money, Jeff rode an old bicycle to work and even used it to go on holiday to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 due to a knee injury, he finally set off in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains on their bikes, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further away from home I got, the more amazed people seemed by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which gave him a serious fever. He was stuck in a hostel bed without medicine for ten long days. He had no money for hospital bills or to get back home. Despite all this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope' that lets us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We know a lot about what they do during the day, but not at night, because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope gives us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat. The work is tough. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and write down notes on every duck I see. The weather has been challenging – some nights are mild, but often it is wet. It is so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to what summer will bring – hours in a lab, where we will analyze our results together. It will be hard to be indoors, but it is necessary. And I wouldn't change it for anything!

Text: 'When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But it's true! I spend my workdays eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is crucial to ensure that customers receive perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from my company. Every week, I get samples from our factory to check their taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, to choose the best ones for our chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I test and taste the products I create, and I share samples with my colleagues, which makes them happy! My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with. It's great to have a private space to work in during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I'm in our food lab, and other times I'm traveling abroad to buy raw materials. This can be challenging because I have a young family. However, I love the variety and lack of routine in my job, although the chocolate itself is still my favorite part! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I've never felt like I didn't want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more chocolate in the evening!'

Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many different skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things such as balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves swinging through the air in front of an amazed audience. During the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can come to some classes to see how their children are doing. 

Sophia explains that for a circus career, performers need to avoid repeating the same acts – it's important to keep performances exciting and full of action. If you want to succeed in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great part of the circus is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important – circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. Training is crucial, but the best performers are those who want to succeed, have creativity, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured or only work a few months each year. But the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only travel with the circus while you're young, and then you need to think about other career options.

The course also teaches business planning. Many former students have started businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. However, Sophia warns that it's not a job for making a lot of money! "The work usually means not having a regular salary. It's also competitive – but a lot of fun!"

You might not know her name or recognize her face, but you've probably heard her voice many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She supports the main singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren't good enough to be lead singers, but that's not true. They often need to be even better. People like Mariam are the true stars of the music industry! 

"What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I'll be asked to sing," she says. "It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes it's a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I'm often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do the job!"

"Excellent musical skills are essential for my work, along with the ability to learn quickly. There's often no sheet music to look at. I'll never forget my first time recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, plus an orchestra. I was scared because if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, and nobody likes that. Recording sessions are long enough already."

"One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers don't always know which musical range is best for the female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it."

Julie Deane started her business with only basic knowledge of fashion. She created a successful company selling 'satchels,' which are traditional school bags. These bags are now sold in famous stores and are popular with celebrities. Before deciding on satchels, Julie considered various business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning. She chose satchels even though many people doubted there was a market for them. Julie was confident in her choice.

From the beginning, Julie involved her family in the business. She worked with her mother, who had no previous career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children's storybooks. Although Julie was not familiar with fashion blogs, they played a crucial role in her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel per week. To generate interest, she sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would mention them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her products grew, as did the speed of production.

Julie enjoys seeing which celebrity will be spotted with a satchel next. Instead of spending money on online advertising, she uses feedback from the internet community to create new and exciting styles. There was a difficult period when another company copied her satchel design. This experience taught her to trust her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors to her office often comment on the positive atmosphere, and employees enjoy working there. There is now a new factory, but Julie believes it is the team that makes the workplace special.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose how to spend their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard to balance training with her schoolwork. 

As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky found it exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing very well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. At 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning competitions for years, but I started to feel tired of it all – and when the excitement stops, there’s no point. Fortunately, I found a new career.’

Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘The first thing we do is teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, and it brings young people together as part of a larger group.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people doubt whether celebrity support is always good for a charity. They think celebrities do it to promote themselves, which can hide the real work of the charity. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Ana Ronson, a singer-songwriter, grew up in Ireland. Her parents weren't musicians, but music was always present in her home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. Ana first sang in front of an audience at school, but she was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to build her confidence. After some time in the club, she sang with 50 other students at a concert and felt happy doing it. 

A year later, Ana's brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them.
