She wrote her first song, "Falling Stars," in just three days and enjoyed the process so much that she took a songwriting course with a professional songwriter. Even though she was the youngest in the class, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt the teacher didn't listen to her, so she wrote a song called "Something to Say" about her frustration. She posted it online, and it became very popular. People loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened.

Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled across Ireland to ask Ana to join his company. At first, Ana was unsure because she didn't know much about the company and didn't want to be told what to sing. Joss assured her this wouldn't happen, and soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and the evening was a great success.

Ana prefers writing songs about difficult times rather than when life is good because she feels there's more to express. One of her favorite songs is "Decision," which is about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it affected him. While she hopes her fans enjoy her music, her main goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an incredible trip. I joined a guided group tour by boat along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry's idea. Like me, he is a journalist, and he wanted to write articles about the trip. Harry loves boats, but I don't share that interest. However, I had always wanted to visit the area since I saw it on TV as a child. I knew our great-grandparents had lived there before moving to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally said yes!

A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we planned to visit. Fortunately, the weather forecast for our trip was for calm seas. I was busy with work and didn't have much time to prepare, but Harry assured me he had taken care of everything, so I stopped worrying.

When we arrived in Canada, we joined the group, packed our limited supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide told us that very few people lived along that coast. On the first morning, the only other living creatures we saw were dolphins and birds. There were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see them. I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water.

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were full of amazing, colorful fish, many of which I didn't recognize. It was wonderful not to worry about time. We always made lunch and dinner together over campfires. At night, we slept on the boats. Even though the beds were hard, it felt like a stress-free life!

When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew I would miss my family and friends if I stayed. I was also excited to tell everyone at home about our adventures!

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. As a kid, I went to watch many of his games. You might think that seeing so many games would make me love basketball, but it actually did the opposite. I loved telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I usually took a book to read instead of watching the games. 

When I started secondary school, I was not yet a teenager but was already two meters tall. Because of my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training session, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, my teacher believed in me more than I did. It took some time for me to agree, but a few weeks later, I played against another school. Having my mom and dad watch made me nervous, but it turned out fine in the end!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did really well. I even joined an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn't enjoy being far from my parents at first. At home, I couldn't spend much time with friends because of all the training, so that part didn't change much. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I was too light for my height, so I had to work on that first. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college and needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. I considered different options and decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my hometown, Chicago, USA. This job involved showing visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I got to see my city through the eyes of tourists, making it feel new every time. After finishing my studies, I chose to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but I learned that to get a license, I needed to know a lot more than I already did. Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, including its architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging months, I earned my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent guide. 

Being a tour guide isn't just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group. You also need to be entertaining, tell interesting stories, and handle unexpected situations, like if a place is closed or a route changes. Tourists want to enjoy a well-organized tour without hearing about problems. I need to ensure visitors are happy with my tours because they might leave reviews online. Good reviews are important as they attract more customers. That's why making tours fun and stress-free is essential. My enthusiasm and energy usually result in very good reviews, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago.

My name is Ella, and I’m 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister Josie. Even though she is five years younger than me, we get along quite well. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would have much in common with the other volunteers because they were much older than us. We were also nervous because it was our first time doing something like this. However, we didn’t need to worry. 

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to gather food for the elephants. Elephants eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so collecting this took most of the day. Josie found it really hard, but seeing the elephants enjoy their food made it worth it for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river using big brushes and soap. I found this very fun, even though I got wetter than the elephants! 

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, so we didn’t have much space. We chose this because Josie didn’t want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and didn’t include meat, which we both prefer to avoid. After dinner, all the volunteers and staff spent the evenings talking and playing games.

Now that we’re back in the UK, Josie doesn’t talk much about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I’m not sure she’s being completely honest. I think she might be a bit upset with herself for not making the most of her time there because she missed her friends too much. But when she looks back, she realizes how lucky she was to go there. Maybe she’ll return one day – I definitely will!

I'm Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We don't just sell flowers to people for their friends or homes; we have many different customers. Hotels and offices often want flowers for their reception areas, and sometimes we provide flowers for business photo shoots. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was very proud of it.

My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep then, and my friends think I'm crazy, but I love what I do. It's often colder and darker than I'd like, but that's normal for that time of the morning, so I don't mind. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were choosing for myself, I'd probably only pick pink ones because it's my favorite color. But I have to remember that what I like and what customers want can be different. Not all flowers are available all year, so sometimes I can't find what customers want.

I don't enjoy arguing about prices with the flower sellers, but it's part of the job. Flowers aren't cheap, so I try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we look at customer orders and arrange the flowers I bought. Then we make flower arrangements and calculate the cost of orders. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some people might think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy figuring out how to create the best flower arrangements for the money someone wants to spend. That's what you have to do when you're selling things, and I wouldn't want any other job!

My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest movies I want to see, and many films for kids on the weekends. It's close to where I live. However, a year ago, I felt something was missing – the chance to talk about a movie in detail with others after watching it. So, with two friends, I started a film club! We decided not to rent a cinema for our screenings. Instead, we pick a different place in the city each month. For example, we rented an old factory to show a movie set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which made the atmosphere perfect for the film, and it was amazing! Some places we use are even free because the owners make money by selling snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We’re happy just to cover our costs – we’re not trying to make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets a bit easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We also know how many tickets we’ve sold because everything is online – no more worries about empty seats! There’s still a lot to do, but when people of all ages come up at the end to say they had a great time, it’s wonderful. The website has been very helpful, and we’re now in touch with other film clubs across the country. We’ve visited to see how others do things – but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We’ve started a blog too, because we know most people now go online for movie information, rather than reading reviews in local newspapers. We’ve also tried putting up a few posters in cafés. However, nothing works as well as word of mouth – people recommending us to their friends. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film – last month, we had a movie quiz, which everyone enjoyed.

As a child, I loved taking photographs. When I was 15, I wanted to take my hobby further, so I started a special project: taking one photo every day for a year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea. After a few weeks, I decided to share my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show my work to others. I was surprised to find that people liked my photos and the way I saw things. I enjoyed taking pictures of many different subjects. Then, someone suggested that my project would be better if all the photos had a common theme. I agreed and started focusing on nature scenes, especially birds and the sky. Many of my photos were in black and white, which was different from what other young photographers were doing, as they mostly took color photos. Sometimes, I doubted my project and almost quit, but I trusted my instincts and became more confident in my style. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher, who told me about a national photography competition for people my age. I entered some of my photos just for fun. I’ll never forget when the judges told me I had won first prize; I was so happy because my project was important to me. It was the first time I realized my photography might be good enough for a career. Now, I have my own photography studio and I’ve never regretted choosing this path.

I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new things like camping, sailing, and public speaking. In the NYC, you can do different activities to push yourself and learn new skills. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, and adult volunteers called 'leaders' run them. When you finish a level, you get a certificate. 

When I first joined, my leader suggested I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I wasn’t sure about it because I had been to that club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other kids already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. But I decided to take the challenge because I wanted my first NYC certificate. Soon, I wanted to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became more important to me than just getting the certificate. 

After I finished the challenge, the NYC leader let me keep volunteering at the club because I had made great connections with the children. Now, I volunteer there for about four hours a week and always look forward to it. Because of my experience at the children’s club, I’ve decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about this career before joining the club. 

This has been my favorite part of the NYC so far, and I’ve improved my communication skills while helping others. I’ve earned several other NYC certificates now, and yes, one of them is for camping!

I was born in Denver, USA. I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, and my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was young and hadn't thought about snowboarding, but my dad loved it and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and eventually, I did well. After that, I quickly grew to love snowboarding and got better at it. I started competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but I love competing and winning, which motivates me to try harder. I like not having a fixed plan. This worked well when I became the first female to score a perfect 100 at a local competition. I wasn't sure I would try the jumps that got me this score until I started. This success made me trust my abilities more. In the summer, I focus on training and studying because there is no snow. I train every day, but I don't have to follow a strict diet like in winter. I also spend a lot of time with my friends. This helps me cope with not being able to snowboard, which I love and am good at. I have to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life, but I also want to have another option in case I don't succeed as a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I'm considering becoming a doctor if I can find time for college. I can't imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can't do it forever.

When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I didn't think about the future. For example, I didn't know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I wanted one too. My parents said I could have it only if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I'm grateful to my parents for this because it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn't enjoy it much. My parents suggested I start my own small business instead. I saw my mum making necklaces for herself, so I asked if I could try it. I was surprised at how easy it was, even though it looked complicated when I watched Mum. My friends thought it was boring, but I was excited about it. Mum showed me how to make beautiful things at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewelry to friends and family. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. I needed to know if other people would like them too. So, I rented a market stall with my mum. There are always many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my jewelry to take home as gifts. Soon, we got calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many employees, but it was just the two of us at a market stall! That's when I realized it could work, and it was time to create a website. Since then, I've made thousands of pounds through my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It's been a lot of fun so far.

When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a novel called "Being Amelia," which became a bestseller. The book is partly inspired by Janine's own life. In an interview, Janine explained that because her father's job required the family to move frequently, she became skilled at making new friends. This experience helped her write about Amelia, the main character, adjusting to a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia's home life, especially her interactions with her older brother. Since Janine is an only child, she had to use her imagination to write those parts.

Janine began writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to start writing. The year before, she had won first prize in a short story competition on a young writers' website. This success made the publishing company eager to read her novel when she sent it to them. They loved it, and a year later, "Being Amelia" was available in bookstores.

A review of "Being Amelia" notes that even though the cover shows happy teenagers, the characters in the story face real challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer says that although Janine is young and the novel isn't very long, she has shown she is a better writer than many bestselling authors.

Janine is still getting used to being famous. She said, "At first, I hid when people recognized me on the street, but now it's OK. I want to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, spending time with my friends gives me new ideas to write about!"

I'm Tom, I'm fifteen, and three years ago, my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. This happened because my dad got a job as the castle's manager. He works for an organization that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open for people to visit. He was happy about the job because he thought he might not get such a great opportunity again. It took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should take the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our cozy home across the water, and there was no school on the island. But after we moved, we quickly got used to living there. The castle isn't very beautiful, but our apartment inside it is comfortable. In the summer, the island feels lively because many visitors come, and there are often beach parties. In the winter, we only see the other families living on the island, and there aren't as many teenagers as I had hoped. The adults help each other with repairs on the island, which can be hard work. The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I was excited about going on stormy days with big waves, but the ferries don't run then! I've learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I miss the last ferry home, which is a problem. So when friends come to stay with me, I always tell them to hurry up! But we often see amazing views, like the sunset over the sea. Some days, it's so foggy you can't see anything, and then a few hours later, it's sunny again – it's still surprising when that happens, even after living here for a while. Of course, we do get terrible storms, and I sometimes worry if the castle is strong enough to avoid damage. But then I remind myself it's been here for centuries – and it's still standing!

I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I've always loved nature and wild animals. Six years ago, I started a new hobby: birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural habitat. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to identify different species and find the best spots to see them. It was amazing, and after we returned home, I joined a local young birdwatchers' club. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I'm almost there. During family holidays abroad, I've had the chance to see birds from other countries too. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities so I can add new birds to my list! I've been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I hoped to see my 200th species. I wasn't too disappointed when it didn't happen because I've learned that patience is important in this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers found it interesting and commented that it looked like a fascinating hobby. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I wasn't nervous until just before I was introduced and walked onto the stage. I knew I would remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I had prepared well and they really enjoyed it. I might even do another one next year! I'm lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think of becoming birdwatchers, but there are actually plenty of birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn't have to cost much money.

I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and soon I became a pretty good player. However, my family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought the same would happen with football. But it didn’t. I was already dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I often played in local tournaments, and one of the referees noticed I was a talented player. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. After that, she invited me to join her club. I couldn’t believe it at first – I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager was impressed, and I started training regularly with a big club when I was just 13. After that, I got much better. Even so, people still doubted I’d become a star player, which made me a bit upset. But the coach encouraged me to be myself and believe in myself – he even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches, much earlier than I expected! I’ve never run so hard in my life – I didn’t want the other players to blame me if we lost. Then, by pure luck, I scored the winning goal. Despite the large crowd, I could clearly hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, the team carried me around the pitch. It was fantastic! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals! Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and give them a chance to talk to other players in my club. It will show them the professional environment and encourage them to believe they could play for a top team if they’re willing to work hard. But my advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me – you’ll have good times, but be ready for bad times too. I’ve had very few bad times, though – so I’ve been lucky!

In recent years, both in the UK and internationally, there has been a trend in higher education to involve students in research early in their studies. This shift acknowledges that research is not just for famous scholars or scientists making big discoveries. Instead, research is a natural way to build knowledge and skills. These skills are valuable not only in academics but also in the workplace, as they help us understand the world and improve our work.

As a student, you contribute to knowledge by creating it, not just by learning and repeating it. This involves asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? These questions are the foundation of research. Research can range from groundbreaking studies by experts to everyday inquiries that involve careful planning and questioning of issues and practices.

Most students have been researchers in some way, whether in school projects or everyday tasks like planning a holiday or fixing things at home. In college, having an enquiring mind, identifying problems, and critically evaluating information are key learning activities. However, some students might find this challenging, especially if they come from cultures where knowledge is seen as fixed and learned from authority figures like teachers and textbooks.

In places like the UK, US, and much of Europe and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authority is encouraged. This can be intimidating, but critical thinking is crucial in research. We need to engage with others' research, think critically about it, and test its validity. It's important not to accept information blindly but to assess whether it is logical and supported by evidence.

Cities have always been places where people come together to share ideas. In the 18th century, London’s coffee houses were popular spots for discussing topics like chemistry and politics. In modern Paris, cafés on the Left Bank were where artist Pablo Picasso talked about modern art. However, living in a city can be difficult. Those same London coffee houses also spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. While cities are great for creativity, they can also be stressful and unnatural places to live.

Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. We’ve known for a long time that living in a city can be tiring, but new research shows that it can also make our thinking less sharp. One major issue is the lack of nature in cities. Studies have shown that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even brief views of nature can help our brains because they give us a break from the busy city life.

This research is important because, for the first time in history, most people now live in cities. Instead of living in open spaces, we are packed into crowded urban areas with millions of strangers. This unnatural environment affects our mental and physical health and changes how we think. Walking down a busy city street, our brains have to deal with many distractions: other pedestrians, traffic, and the complex layout of the city. These tasks use up a lot of our brain’s energy because we have to constantly decide what to pay attention to and what to ignore.

In contrast, natural environments don’t require as much mental effort. This idea is called attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He suggested that being in nature can help restore our ability to focus. Nature captures our attention without causing stress, unlike city noises like police sirens. This allows our minds to relax and recharge.

Long before scientists studied these effects, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the negative impact of city life and looked for ways to bring nature into cities. Urban parks, like Central Park in New York, offer people a break from city life. A well-designed park can quickly improve brain function. While people have tried many ways to boost brain performance, like energy drinks or changing office layouts, simply walking in nature seems to be one of the most effective methods.

Despite the mental challenges of city life, cities continue to grow. Even in the digital age, they remain centers of intellectual activity. Research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same city features that can make us lose focus, like crowded streets, also lead to innovation. The high level of social interaction in cities is a big reason for their creativity. Just as 18th-century London’s crowded environment led to new ideas, today’s busy cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, are successful creative hubs.

The challenge is to reduce the negative effects of city life while keeping its benefits. After all, there are times when people crave the excitement of the city, even if they miss the peace of nature.

Where should we look for the mind? It might seem obvious to say that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain-scanning technology to support this idea. However, I believe that the study of the mind shouldn't be limited to just the brain. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects and tools also play a role in how we think. Archaeology shows us that things like stone tools, jewelry, engravings, clay tokens, and writing systems have been important in human evolution and shaping our minds. So, I suggest that what is outside our heads might still be part of our minds.

It's easy to see why people think the mind and brain are the same. Most of our knowledge about the mind comes from studying people in isolation from their usual surroundings. This makes sense for neuroscientists because of the limitations of brain-scanning machines. But this approach often overlooks the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I don't deny that the brain is crucial for thinking, but I want to highlight that the mind is more than just the brain. It might be more useful to consider that human intelligence extends beyond our bodies into our culture and the material world.

This is where my new theory, Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes in. MET explores how objects become extensions of our minds or are integrated into our bodies. For example, when we make numbers and symbols out of clay or use a stone to make a tool. It also looks at how these interactions have changed over time and what they mean for our thinking. This approach offers new insights into what minds are and how they are shaped by the things around us.

Consider a blind person using a stick. Where does this person's sense of self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick shows how minds and objects can be continuous. It also illustrates the flexibility of the human mind: the stick helps the blind person turn touch into sight, and the brain treats the stick as part of the body. This example reminds us that human intelligence is adaptable and can change significantly by incorporating new technologies.

I see the human mind as an ongoing project, always evolving. Throughout history, the 'stick'—whether it was a stone tool or the internet—has served as a pathway for humans to explore and understand the world, not as a boundary. This is different from how a monkey uses a stick to get food. For humans, 'sticks' help satisfy our curiosity. This unique human tendency to engage with material culture explains why we create things and how those things shape our minds.

I call this metaplasticity—our minds are flexible and change as they interact with the material world. I want to include materiality in our understanding of cognition. MET provides a new way to see how different forms of material culture, from ancient tools to modern smartphones, have defined and transformed who we are and how we think. While mind-changing technology might sound futuristic, humans have been using it since we first evolved.

Photography has greatly influenced civilization and how we understand the world, especially in the United States. In the U.S., photography quickly became a part of culture at all levels, from practical and scientific uses to industrial and artistic ones. It also brought new forms of entertainment with the invention of the camera. Historians argue that photography is perhaps the U.S.'s most significant contribution to the visual arts, more so than any other art form. This highlights how photography has become central to U.S. intellectual and artistic discussions, and to fully appreciate its impact, we need to look at its origins in the mid-19th century.

Why was photography so attractive? First, because it was a mechanical process, it fit well with the growing interest in technology in the U.S., where change was seen as a normal part of life. Just like steam power, railroads, and electricity made the world feel smaller by improving communication and travel, photography brought the wonders of the world into people's homes with stunning immediacy. Second, the camera was the preferred tool for representing oneself, allowing people to create and share images in a country where personal and national identities were always evolving. Third, the camera played a crucial role in creating and preserving family memories, even if these were somewhat idealized. Lastly, the realistic nature of photographs matched the U.S. artists' tendency towards realism and depicting everyday life. 

A photograph draws attention to what the photographer wants us to see, saying, "This, you should see!" Because a photograph is made by a machine, it serves as a record of events, people, or things, providing a sense of objectivity. However, since it is taken by an individual, it also carries a personal perspective, or subjectivity. We might think we understand a photograph because we recognize the subject, leading to the idea of photography as a "universal language." But the meaning of a photograph is more complex. No image is shown to us without some context that affects our understanding, like a newspaper caption, a magazine layout, or its placement in a gallery or book. To understand a photograph historically, we must consider its purpose and role in its cultural context: Why did the photographer take it? How was it first seen? The same image can appear in different places and times, changing its meaning each time.

For a long time, the camera's importance to artists was not widely acknowledged, but now it is well recognized. Since the time of U.S. artist Andy Warhol, who used photographs in his paintings, silk screens, and other works, artists have been incorporating photographs into their art in various ways. In summary, photographic vision has become an essential part of art history, not opposing painting but complementing it, and is crucial to our understanding of representation before the camera was invented.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and one of the founders of modern psychology, described psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still useful today. We all have a mental life, so we have some idea of what this means. However, even though we can study mental life in animals like rats and monkeys, it is still a complex concept. James, like most psychologists, was mainly interested in human psychology. He believed it included basic elements: thoughts and feelings, a physical world in time and space, and a way to understand these things. Our knowledge of these is personal and private, coming from our own thoughts, feelings, and experiences. It might be influenced by scientific facts, but often it is not. This personal understanding makes us feel like amateur psychologists when we give opinions on complex psychological topics, like brainwashing or why people behave in certain ways, such as feeling insulted or unhappy. Problems occur when people have different understandings. Formal psychology tries to find methods to decide which explanations are most likely correct in a situation. Psychologists help us tell the difference between subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and scientific facts. Psychology, as James defined it, is about the mind or brain. Psychologists study the brain, but they do not fully understand how it affects our hopes, fears, and behaviors. It is hard to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming ideas about what happens inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective and verifiable, but the mind's workings are not directly observable like an engine's. We can only infer them from behavior. Psychology is like solving a crossword puzzle, using clues from careful observation and analysis. Complex interactions are common in psychology, and understanding them requires advanced techniques and theories. Psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to control or change the processes it studies. Achieving these goals helps us understand our experiences and apply conclusions to real life. Psychological findings have been useful in many areas, like teaching children to read, designing safer machines, and helping people communicate their feelings better. Although people have discussed psychological questions for centuries, scientific investigation began only about 150 years ago. Early psychologists used introspection, or reflecting on one's own conscious experience, to answer questions. They aimed to identify mental structures, which is still important today. However, introspection has limitations. As Sir Francis Galton noted, it only shows a small part of brain activity. William James compared trying to understand the mind through introspection to "turning up the gas quickly enough to see how the darkness looks." Modern psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of behavior rather than personal reflections.

In a warehouse in a typical business park in Michigan, USA, there is a place known as the Museum of Failed Products. This museum is like a graveyard for consumer goods that didn’t succeed in the market. Here, you can find unusual items like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola, which were taken off the shelves because almost no one wanted to buy them. The museum is owned by a company called GfK, and its owner, Carol Sherry, believes each product tells a sad story about the designers, marketers, and salespeople who created it.

What’s surprising about the museum is that it exists as a profitable business. You might think that companies would keep their own collections of failed products, but many don’t. Executives visit the museum regularly, showing how rare it is for companies to keep track of their failures. The museum started by accident. Robert McMath, a former marketing professional, began collecting new products in the 1960s to create a ‘reference library,’ not specifically a collection of failures. However, since most products fail, his collection naturally became filled with unsuccessful items.

Today’s culture of optimism might explain why these failed products exist. Each product likely went through many meetings where no one realized it was doomed. Even if they did, marketers might have continued investing in the product to force some sales and save face. Little effort is made to understand why these products failed, and people involved often avoid discussing it.

This focus on optimism is common in the growing ‘self-help’ industry. A popular method is ‘positive visualization,’ which suggests that imagining success makes it more likely to happen. Neuroscientist Tali Sharot has found evidence that our brains might be wired to be overly optimistic. Her research shows that well-balanced people often have an unrealistic, positive view of their ability to influence events, unlike those with depression.

Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen has studied whether ‘positive fantasies about the future’ are effective. Her research shows that thinking too much about success can actually reduce motivation to achieve goals. For example, people who imagined having a successful week at work ended up achieving less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck suggests that our beliefs about ability affect how we handle failure. People with a ‘fixed theory’ mindset think ability is innate and find failure distressing because it shows they didn’t measure up. In contrast, those with an ‘incremental theory’ believe ability grows with effort and see failure as a chance to improve. Dweck compares this to weight training, where muscles grow stronger after being pushed to their limits. Having an incremental mindset is a happier way to live, regardless of success.

Sports teams often have an advantage when playing at home, but the reasons for this are not entirely clear. Traditionally, people believed that playing at home helped teams perform better, but changes in professional sports have led to questions about this belief. Two main factors challenging this idea are science and money. Sports scientists are exploring what helps players perform at their best, and they have come up with many theories about home advantage. On the other hand, financial interests question if home advantage should matter, as well-paid players should perform well anywhere.

Fans play a role in this discussion. For example, if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East, it might upset British fans who believe their support is crucial for the team's success. Fans often think their cheering leads to goals, but they forget the times when their support didn't result in success. However, scientific studies show that home fans can influence referees. In an experiment, referees who watched a match with crowd noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team compared to those who watched in silence. This suggests referees might avoid decisions that would anger the home crowd.

Research shows that home advantage has decreased over time in major sports, but it still exists. In the 1890s, home teams in England's Football League won about 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. Travel used to be difficult, but now players travel in comfort, and stadiums are more similar. Despite these changes, home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the highest home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. This might be because basketball relies more on teamwork, which is boosted by playing at home.

Another factor could be players' testosterone levels, which are higher before home games. This might be linked to a natural instinct to defend home territory. In the Rugby World Cup, underdog teams playing at home won against stronger opponents, showing the power of home advantage. As one referee said, "It's the law of the jungle out there."

"The more I practise, the luckier I get," said golfer Gary Player about 50 years ago. This saying is famous in sports and is valued by athletes and coaches. The quote's origin is debated, with claims that other golfers might have said it. The meaning is also not straightforward. Player didn't mean actual luck; he meant that practice makes you better. This idea connects to the nature-nurture debate: is talent something you're born with, or can it be developed? 

In this debate, nurture, or practice, has been seen as more important than natural talent. Psychologist Anders Ericsson suggested that becoming an expert in any field requires 10,000 hours of practice. This idea was popularized by Malcolm Gladwell's book "Outliers" and others like "Talent Is Overrated" and "Bounce: The Myth of Talent and the Power of Practice." These books argue that practice is the key to success, and that 10,000 hours is enough to make anyone an expert.

However, in his book, Epstein challenges this idea. He shows through many examples that practice alone is not always enough. He points out that studies often focus only on successful people, which can be misleading. Epstein explores why some people have certain abilities and others don't, looking at factors like environment, support, and determination. His research takes him around the world, from Kenya to Sweden, and even to the Arctic.

In Alaska, Epstein learns that in a tough sled dog race, the huskies' drive and desire are crucial, suggesting that both genes and environment play a role. This challenges the idea that commitment and determination are just choices. What if, as with the huskies, an individual's drive also has a genetic component?

Epstein talks about the complexity of talent, distinguishing between "hardware" (nature) and "software" (nurture). He agrees that both are important for elite athletes. He doesn't dismiss the role of training or environment, suggesting that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have become a basketball player instead of the fastest man in history. But Epstein also shows cases where genetics are very important.

He also discusses race and gender, asking why men and women compete separately in sports if practice is all that matters. Sometimes, the simplest questions are the most important.

A recent international report shows that many children in rich countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks why this is happening. In her book, "Kith," she suggests that children are unhappy because they spend too much time indoors, in front of screens, and have lost touch with nature. She believes this is the main problem. This idea is supported by other discussions about modern childhood. A follow-up study interviewed children and found that many would be happier if they could spend more time outside. People over 40 often remember their own childhoods fondly, recalling how they spent time exploring outdoors, which they believe was healthier than the way children live today. However, they don't often realize that they are the ones who have created the protective environment for their children, avoiding risks like playing in old sheds.

Griffiths' book includes strong arguments. She discusses how fear of outdoor dangers and consumerism are connected. Parents' fears keep children indoors, which benefits the toy and gadget industry. She also criticizes trends like giving medication to restless children or making them wear goggles for playground games. While some of these rules might be exaggerated, Griffiths expresses her frustration clearly. She also talks about childhood freedoms and restrictions, from fairy tales to school rules. Although her arguments are interesting, Griffiths sometimes takes them too far. She ignores important counter-arguments and even compares modern treatment of children to racism, which seems extreme.

Griffiths is very idealistic about children. She mostly sees them in a positive light, which might not match the reality of dealing with energetic young kids. She believes children are naturally creative thinkers, but this might not be true for all. The main idea of her book is that children should have the freedom to explore and take risks. She argues that children need small accidents to learn how to handle bigger risks later. However, she doesn't explain how to ensure these accidents are "the right size." Also, not all children might want the adventurous life she describes. Some children are naturally more cautious and prefer staying indoors. The real issue might be forcing all children into the same lifestyle, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.

I'm a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I've spent a lot of time in school. I'm good at solving problems in my work and life, but this isn't because of my schooling. Most life problems can't be solved with complex formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity, which come from life experiences. For children, these experiences come from play. My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All young mammals, including humans, play. Those with more to learn play more. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because their lives depend more on learning than on instincts. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can. Play is how adults and mammals have always learned. The most important skills for children to live happy, productive, moral lives can't be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced through play. They include creativity, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling impulses and emotions. Creativity is crucial for economic success. We don't need people to follow instructions like robots or do routine calculations. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can develop thinkers who anticipate obstacles, we'll have a strong workforce. This requires creative thinking. A creative mind is a playful mind. Geniuses are adults who keep and build on their childlike creativity. Albert Einstein said school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He called his innovative work 'combinatorial play.' He developed his theory of relativity by imagining himself chasing a sunbeam. We can't teach creativity, but we can suppress it with schooling focused on imposed questions with one right answer. More important than creativity is getting along with others, caring for them, and cooperating. Children are born wanting to play with others, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality. Play is voluntary, meaning players can quit. If you can't quit, it's not play. Players know they must keep others happy to continue the game. This makes play the most democratic activity. School has become more demanding: breaks are shorter, homework has increased, and pressure for high grades has grown. Outside school, adult-directed sports have replaced spontaneous games. 'Play dates' with adults present have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults now intervene instead of letting children solve their own problems. These changes have been gradual but significant. They result from social factors like parents' fears, expert warnings about dangers, declining neighborhood cohesion, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children don't need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must reverse the trend of the past fifty years. We must give childhood back to children. They need to follow their natural drives to play and explore to grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Platforms like Twitter and LinkedIn allow them to directly contact potential employers, which used to be possible only by standing outside an office with a "hire me" sign. However, this increased access also means more chances to make mistakes. For example, a young jobseeker in the US reached out to a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many important contacts, and the jobseeker hoped they could help him get a job. But the executive was not pleased. She was upset that a stranger expected her to share her valuable contacts and sent him a harsh rejection note, which went viral online. Many people who saw the note were shocked, and the executive might regret her tone, even if not the message. However, this incident might help young people think more carefully about using social media professionally. It highlights that social media can be risky for job seekers who don't know how to use it properly, and many are making mistakes.

There's an irony here because social media sites like Facebook and Twitter have been central to the social lives of people in their twenties for years. When my generation was young, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers. It was like an online playground where we could impress others and try new things. It was often based on fantasy. You could chat with someone online for hours and then ignore them at school. By choosing certain pictures or songs for your Facebook page, you could become a different, more interesting person overnight. And if you didn't want to talk, you could just "poke" people on Facebook.

However, using social media for professional networking is very different. For some people in their twenties, this difference is not clear. We first became known online by being bold and confident, which might explain why some of us still think this is a good approach. Just because many people "liked" your Facebook posts doesn't mean you can use LinkedIn to show employers you're worth hiring. We need to understand that what we learned about social networking as teenagers doesn't apply anymore. We must meet employers' standards if we want to succeed in the job market.

One common complaint from employers about young job seekers on professional networking sites is that they are too informal and seem arrogant. This reinforces the stereotype of our generation as "entitled." In reality, many of us are desperate to find jobs, which is why we turn to social media. This impression of arrogance can hurt the job prospects of young people who, despite their communication mistakes, have the skills and motivation to be valuable employees.

So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them, like doing research or helping in some way. This approach increases your chances of getting a positive response. Avoid sending generic emails and keep your tone humble to avoid offending the recipient. Remember, social media can be a great way to make useful contacts, but it requires careful handling to avoid negative outcomes.

Predicting the future of newspapers is very difficult. If you look at the numbers, it seems like newspapers are in trouble. Since 2000, the circulation of most UK national newspapers has dropped by a third to half. In the USA, only 26% of people now get their news from newspapers, compared to 45% in 2001, according to the Pew Research Centre. Many people predict that printed newspapers will disappear in about 15 years. However, history shows that old media often survive. For example, in 1835, a New York journalist claimed that books and theatre were outdated, but both have survived alongside newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has thrived even with TV, and cinema has stayed popular despite videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records are popular again, with sales increasing by 745% since 2008.

Newspapers were once new media too, but it took centuries for them to become the main source of news. This happened in the mid-19th century with the steam press, railway, and telegraph, which made it possible to produce and distribute news widely. Another important factor was the idea that everything is constantly changing, and people need regular updates, a concept that was not common in medieval times. Back then, people only noticed the changing seasons and unexpected disasters like famine or disease. Life was seen as cyclical, with recurring truths, as writer Alain de Botton explains.

Journalism as a full-time job only became common in the 19th century. Even then, there was no clear reason why people needed news regularly. The regular publication of newspapers can be limiting. Online news allows readers to check updates as they see fit. Advanced search engines and algorithms let us customize news to our interests. Online news can provide minute-by-minute updates, correct errors quickly, and offer detailed analysis without space limits. This is very different from traditional newspapers.

However, many online news providers focus on being the first to report news, encouraging reader comments, and creating excitement, which can lead to confusion. In medieval times, news was shared in busy places like markets or taverns, where truth mixed with rumors. In some ways, we are returning to that environment. Newspapers have not always been great at explaining how the world works. They might face extinction, or they might find a way to help us understand the world better, as the internet adds to our feeling of living in a chaotic universe, as de Botton suggests.

If humans were truly comfortable under the moon and stars, we would enjoy the darkness, seeing the midnight world as clearly as many night-active animals do. However, we are creatures of the day, with eyes suited for sunlight. This is a fundamental part of our genetics, even if we don't often think of ourselves as day creatures, just like we don't constantly think of ourselves as primates or mammals. This explains why we have changed the night by filling it with light. We've engineered the night to suit us, similar to how we control rivers with dams. This control has benefits but also leads to problems, known as light pollution, which scientists are just beginning to study. Light pollution mainly comes from poor lighting design, where artificial light shines into the sky instead of focusing downward. This bad lighting brightens the night, changing the natural light levels and rhythms that many living things, including humans, have adapted to. Wherever artificial light enters the natural world, it affects life processes like migration, reproduction, and feeding. For most of human history, the idea of 'light pollution' would have been meaningless. Imagine approaching London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the world's largest city. Nearly a million people lived there, using candles, torches, and lanterns. Only a few homes had gas lighting, and public gaslights wouldn't appear for another seven years. From a few miles away, you would have smelled London before seeing its faint glow. We've lit up the night as if it were empty, but that's not true. Many mammals are active at night. Light is a strong biological force and attracts many species. This attraction is so strong that scientists say songbirds and seabirds are 'captured' by searchlights or gas flares, flying around them until they fall. Birds migrating at night often crash into brightly lit tall buildings, with young birds on their first journey being most affected. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at odd times when exposed to artificial light. It was once thought that light pollution only bothered astronomers, who need a clear night sky. Unlike astronomers, most of us don't need a perfect view of the night sky for work, but like most creatures, we need darkness. Ignoring the need for darkness is pointless. Darkness is as important for our health as light. Changing our natural rhythms can cause health problems. The regular cycle of waking and sleeping reflects the Earth's light cycle. These rhythms are so essential that disrupting them is like changing our balance. In the end, humans are as affected by light pollution as frogs near a bright highway. Living in our own bright world, we have disconnected from our evolutionary and cultural roots—the stars and the natural day-night cycle. Light pollution makes us lose our sense of place in the universe and forget our true scale, which is best understood under a deep night sky with the Milky Way above.

The founder of a large international company recently said that his company will stop tracking how much paid holiday time employees take. This idea was inspired by an internet company that has a similar policy. The founder got the idea from an email from his daughter, which seemed like it was written by someone from his media team. While the announcement might seem like an attempt to make the company look more caring, we should ask: is this idea practical?

The internet company and the multinational corporation are very different. The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the multinational has 50,000 employees and many different services like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want as long as it doesn't harm the business" might work better in a smaller company where employees know each other's work better. In a large company, it's harder to be sure that taking time off won't cause problems.

The founder said employees can take as much leave as they want if they are sure their work and team projects are up to date and their absence won't harm the business or their careers. But can anyone be that sure? Even if you prepare well before a holiday, there will always be work waiting when you return. This is just how taking leave works. If employees follow these rules, they might not take any leave at all or feel guilty about it. Feeling guilty can lead to stress, and not taking enough leave can reduce productivity over time.

There could also be pressure from colleagues and office gossip about who takes time off and for how long. This pressure already affects decisions like when to start and end the workday. In the corporate world, there's a culture of working late, and this could lead to a "no holiday" culture in a company with unlimited leave, where employees compete for promotions. Without the security of guaranteed leave, people might feel they can't take the time off they need because they don't want to seem lazy. They wouldn't have their legal right to leave to rely on.

The policy might make employees feel stuck, unable to take their leave, or they might just stick to their legal rights, making the policy pointless. Modern technology lets us get work messages anytime, anywhere, blurring the line between work and free time. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy because employees wondered how this new way of working fit with the old time-off rules. If the company can't track work hours accurately, why should it use an outdated standard for time off?

However, if there are no set work hours, all hours could become work hours. Employees might not know if their work hours are being watched, making them monitor themselves, which could be harmful. Employment laws exist for a reason. Workers have a right to a minimum amount of paid leave because rest is important for their health. The benefits like increased morale, creativity, and productivity that are expected from the unlimited leave policy can happen without affecting worker well-being. I doubt that letting employees "take as much holiday as they want" is the real goal or likely result of this policy.

Journal-based peer review is a process where experts in a field review a scientific paper before it is published. This is seen as a way to ensure the quality of research, acting as a filter to stop flawed or nonsensical papers from being published. Scientists often reassure the public and media about its importance. However, reviewing can delay publication by up to a year, raising the question of whether this delay is worth it to ensure trustworthy research. The answer is both yes and no, as the world of scientific publishing is changing.

I still believe in some form of peer review before formal publication, but things are shifting. Preprints, which are drafts of papers shared online without peer review, are becoming more common. They allow for quick sharing of new results, which can then be read, critiqued, and built upon by others. Publishing in journals has become more about gaining recognition and advancing careers, which can lead to authors cutting corners to get published in top journals. Reviewers now often focus on whether a paper is suitable for a journal rather than its quality. This can depend on how newsworthy a paper is, not just its scientific value.

These issues are well-known, but few are willing to change the current system. However, preprints might offer a solution because they don't require a big change from the norm. Although preprints have been around for twenty years, they are not widely used. This is partly because scientists are conservative and because there is a misconception that journals won't accept papers that have been posted as preprints. There is also a fear that publishing without peer review could lead to 'junk science,' but this hasn't happened yet. Authors know that preprints are open to critique by a global community.

Tanya Elks, a psychology professor, shared her experience with preprints. Her paper critiqued another published paper, which is difficult to do in traditional journals. With preprints, the original authors could respond, and all discussions were open for readers to see. This transparency allows readers to judge the quality of the arguments. Even if a journal rejects the paper, the preprint and comments are still available, so the work isn't wasted.

Preprint archives allow for global scientific discussions that used to happen only between individuals. They can also be a place to share negative results, which are important but often ignored by journals focused on new discoveries. Preprints increase how often papers are read and cited, showing their effectiveness in spreading information. By using the internet's openness and the collaborative spirit of the scientific community, preprints can help focus attention on the research itself, not just where it is published.

When I ask my literature students to define a poem, they often say it's like "a painting in words." These answers usually don't satisfy either of us. So, one day, I asked them to pick an object and write two paragraphs: one describing it like a scientist would, and another from the object's perspective, titled "Poem." One student wrote:

Poem: I may look strange or scary, but I'm a device that helps people breathe. I'm only used in emergencies and even then, only for a short time. Most people will never need me.

The object? An oxygen mask. This unusual choice helped the class see how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise was fun and sparked a lot of discussion. When I was in school, poetry often seemed confusing to me. I thought of each poem as a silly puzzle that blocked true understanding and feeling. After school, many people find poetry less and less engaging. Sometimes you come across a poem, and it stands out because it's not like regular prose. It almost challenges you to read it, and often, you feel let down by its simplicity or because it’s hard to understand at first. Still, you feel good for trying.

What do we expect from poems? Aren’t they supposed to be full of deep emotions, beautiful images, gentle thoughts, or sharp humor? The answer might seem to be yes. But if we want to cry, we watch movies; for information or sharp critique, we read online articles. Novels let us escape to different worlds, paintings please our eyes, and music – well, nothing beats the mix of lyrics, instruments, and melody. Yet, a poem can offer something unique: ambiguity. Everyday life is full of it, unlike straightforward reading. But these thoughts still don’t explain what a poem really is.

If you search online for "poem," it leads you to "poetry," described as a form of art using the beauty and rhythm of language. This is academic language, but it hides the word's origins. "Poem" comes from the Greek "poí?ma," meaning "a thing made," and a poet is "a maker of things." So, if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it? Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals – untameable and unpredictable – or to machines – precise and human-made – depending on their view. But these comparisons don't hold up under scrutiny. The value in comparing a poem to something else is not in the comparison itself but in the discussion it creates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you think about machines or wild animals. It helps the mind explore new ways of thinking and see ordinary things differently.

Thinking of a poem as a mental object is not hard, especially when we consider how song lyrics can stick in our minds. The mix of words and melody is powerful, like schoolyard rhymes such as "Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me." But aren’t words sometimes like sticks and stones? Think about a poem on a newspaper or magazine page, staring at you: A poem can make a strong impact like nothing else, even though, as ink on paper, it does nothing more than the prose around it. What about all the empty space around the poem – space that could have been used for a longer article or ad? A poem is written and rewritten like an article, story, or novel, but it never really becomes a commodity. Publishers send out press releases and review copies of poetry collections, but few expect them to make a profit. A poem presents itself not as something for sale, but as something for its own sake. Because of its special place in a magazine or book, a poem can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. Back then, £70 was a lot of money, and it might have been wiser to spend it on something useful for the house. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. Over the years, every brooch and coin I've found has made me happy because it connects me to the past. But after finding the gold ring, it took 40 years to make another discovery that impressed Marion as much.

One dull February afternoon, I had a couple of hours free and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a closer spot that mostly had old farming machinery. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it but couldn't leave without checking. I dug down half a meter and was lying in the mud when I saw a rounded, golden ball. I had found brass curtain rails before, so I tried not to get too excited. But as I cleared more dirt, the ball turned into a thick, intricately designed loop. I stopped and stared, then remembered to breathe. It looked like the Great Torc, a famous piece from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years ago. A torc is a beautiful necklace made of gold and silver, with gold rings at each end, just like the one I found.

I took it to the car and kept looking at it on the drive home. I washed it in my kitchen sink, probably the first clean it had in ages. I called Marion and said, "I've got something for you." She came in, stopped, and asked, "What is it?" I explained it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn't try it on because we didn't want to damage it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. We had never been burgled, but I was anxious, so I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it there.

The law says you must report such finds to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as possible before giving it up. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone when I put the torc on his desk. He turned, still talking, then stopped mid-sentence. The torc was authenticated and eventually sold to my local council. It's now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 proceeds were split between the field's owner and me. But the torc is more than just a lucky find. It's something I've saved for the nation. People ask me, "Now that you've found something amazing, are you going to stop detecting?" But those brooches and coins are still interesting. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn't stop fishing—he keeps going, hoping for an even bigger catch tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my favorite things to do when I travel, but I don't often talk about it because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends tell me about their carefully planned trips, filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and listen. I wonder what they would think if they knew my travel plans include time for afternoon naps during sudden Caribbean rainstorms and lazy mornings in comfortable Italian beds. Sleeping better is a nice bonus of traveling. When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—more than 12 hours most days. Even though there were noisy birds nearby, it didn't bother me. Away from home, in a new place with different smells and sounds, I could sleep deeply and have vivid dreams. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. But I don't think just relaxing explains why travel sleep feels so different. I believe sleep is part of the travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we experience new sights, sounds, smells, and ways of living. We take in new cultures, music, landscapes, and even ways of moving. During sleep, we process all this new information. That's why sleep feels more intense when we travel. Sleep also changes with each place we visit. People often worry about jet lag, but I think adjusting to local customs affects me more than time zones. On the Caribbean island of Trinidad, people wake up early to avoid the heat, rest around 10 a.m., and become active again in the evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, where I live, it takes me days to get used to their sleep patterns. Once I do, I feel like I've truly arrived. I remember an afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a big lunch with new friends. After eating, we all felt sleepy and lay down on hammocks and sofas. I realized why there were so many pillows on the floor. I joined them and experienced the Latin American tradition of the siesta. I didn't just sleep; I shared a part of Dominican life. Travel sleep is also memorable. Being in a different place with new smells, textures, and sounds makes sleep special. If 'slow travel' means enjoying every moment instead of rushing, then sleep is the slowest activity of all. Maybe I should stop feeling guilty and tell my friends that travel sleep is an important part of the experience too.

The woman turned away from the mirror and asked, "What do you think? And be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a soft layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one suits you best," she said diplomatically to her customer. The woman wrinkled her nose and frowned, looking a bit like a bulldog. "But it's so boring," she complained. "Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little beauty will make me stand out." She patted the red and black mini top hat on her head. "Yes," she decided, "this is the one I want." Mia knew she couldn't change the woman's mind, so she smiled and agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at the wedding. 

Mia thought about her own daughter, Jen, whose thirtieth birthday was today. They were having a family gathering, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious to meet Jen's friend, Tattie, whom they knew nothing about. When Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie, Mia's husband, Jeff, had questioned the name. "Tattie," he said, "What sort of name is that?" Mia explained, "It's short for Tatiana. I think it’s nice." Jeff, who disliked anything showy, replied, "It sounds affected." He also didn't like Mia's tendency to be overly polite. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat, maybe even saying a dustbin lid would suit her better. "The trouble with you, Mia," he often said, "is that you’re too polite for your own good."

An hour later, Mia closed her shop and entered Medlar House through the back door. Her commute was only forty seconds. Four years ago, when their youngest child, Luke, left home, Mia decided to convert the unused barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. "Do you really think there's a demand for hats?" he asked. Mia knew there was, as her friends often complained about finding the perfect hat for special occasions. She was right. After Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became a success. Women traveled from far away to her showroom in Little Pelham, where they could try on as many hats as they wanted in a relaxed setting. She encouraged customers to bring their outfits to ensure everything matched. Recently, she expanded her business to include handbags and costume jewelry.

Lawrence Okoye has come a long way from London to Atlanta. In his new American home, he reflects on his incredible sports journey. He is confident, but even he is surprised by how far he has come—from competing in the Olympic discus final to possibly joining a major American football team. Despite never playing American football before, Lawrence is likely to be chosen by a top team in the USA. In Atlanta, he is still learning the details of his new position. The idea that a 21-year-old from London could be selected for a top American sports team seems unbelievable. But Lawrence is used to proving people wrong. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but delayed it to focus on discus, after playing rugby. In just 20 months, he became the world’s fourth-best discus thrower. Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather discus training, aiming for the world championships. When asked about his sudden interest in a big NFL contract, he says, "American football was always in the back of my mind, but I decided to try it when I got to the USA. I had thought about it in school, but it seemed crazy then." Soon after arriving in America, he learned about NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played, he thought he might be good enough to try out. "Pretty much," he says. "I went online and applied." Was he nervous about competing with experienced players? "No," he says. "I don’t get nervous about many things." He doesn’t talk much, but he clearly believes in himself. His performance in tests and drills made him stand out as the most impressive player. "I was very pleased to hear that," he admits, showing a rare sign of pride. However, he is also cautious. He knows he lacks experience. How can someone so new to the sport make it into an NFL team? "Coaches say I have all the qualities needed. It’s just about how hard I work," he explains. Is he relaxed while waiting to hear if he’s been selected? "I am. There’s no pressure on me. Many people think I’ll be chosen, but I’m not too worried." This calm attitude might come from his disappointing Olympic discus final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved past this and is proud he made it to the final with an impressive last throw. "That was an amazing day," he recalls. "The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s part of sport. I can always return to it." After the Olympics, some thought the experience had affected him negatively. Lawrence doesn’t comment on this.
