The minimum salary for an NFL player is over $400,000 a year, so the financial benefits are clear. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With his great physical abilities, wouldn’t it be better to focus on one sport? "I understand why someone might say that," he replies. "I’m trying to achieve something I dreamed of as a schoolkid. If it doesn’t work out, I can go back to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been well thought out."

We had been flying east all night, and when I woke up, it was already daylight. Looking out the window, I saw the vast, empty landscape below. The dark shades of brown and green reassured me that, even though it was mid-September, winter hadn't started in Siberia yet. There was no sign of human life, just an endless view of mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head in disbelief. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said with a slow, Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow traveling to remote areas to sell safety clothing to local mining industries. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I managed to explain that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with only a one-way ticket because I planned to return to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he reasoned, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I explained that I believed there was a road, though not many people used it anymore. "Alone?" he asked, pointing at me. "No, I will be riding with a friend named Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked doubtful and said one word, "Holodna" (cold), pointing outside. I tried to reassure him with hand gestures that I had a lot of warm clothes, though I didn't mention that my trip was self-funded and I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at discounted prices. In reality, I wasn't sure they would be good enough, especially my large postman's over-trousers, which I bought for £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. That morning, the hall was full of students slumped in their seats, some taking notes without much energy. The lecturer droned on, and I was thinking hard about a particular dilemma. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In the row in front of me sat Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my messy handwriting, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read. "OK," it said. Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still far from having full control of my classes, the job ticked many important boxes for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, often fulfilling, and, of course, there were long holidays to chase adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I had used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug in a big way after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more relaxing than teaching: cycling around the world. Ever since that first ride we took together, Al had been setting himself greater and greater challenges. This round-the-world-by-bike trip was certainly his greatest so far. At times, he thought the ride or the road would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him in many ways. He was having an extraordinary adventure, finding that he could handle each new challenge even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong the skeptics who said he couldn't do it. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.

In the Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns racing through a series of tall pylons, which are between 15 and 25 meters high. They have to make sharp turns, do barrel rolls, and loops, all while flying at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it's like to participate in this race. 

An hour before the flight, I had to sign two forms. The first one confirmed that I was in good health, and the second one was to ensure I emptied my pockets because small objects can become dangerous during the flight. I also learned that I needed to stay oriented during the flight. I was told, "The horizon is your best friend," and the pilot would tell me where to look. I was also asked to promise that when flying upside down, I would "completely relax and try to enjoy the view."

Half an hour before the flight, I attended a safety briefing where I was told not to touch anything under any circumstances. By the time we were moving down the runway, with my legs up and trying not to touch the important steering pedals, and my hands avoiding the many switches, I decided I would not relax and enjoy the flight. This is the tricky part of high-speed acrobatic flying. To avoid passing out, you have to stay calm and focused. You need to tense up at the right time and relax at the right time. Panicking is not a good idea. None of this was comforting as we started speeding down the runway.

Dario, the pilot, and I reached the end of the runway in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes in the world. The plane took off, and two seconds later, we made a sharp right turn. It was a sudden, intense move, and I felt the air push out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and took short breaths as I sank into the seat. For a moment, I felt like I weighed 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out. We made another sharp left turn and dived, leaving my stomach at 2,000 meters and my lungs feeling compressed. Seconds later, we were flying 10 meters above the ground, heading for the small gap between two pylons. They passed by at 400 km per hour, but my brief excitement was interrupted by a sharp right turn. We hadn't even started the acrobatics yet.

For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane. My hand was shaking so much that the plane shook too—it’s that sensitive. Then Dario said something, and I asked him to repeat it. Instead of replying, he did a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. "Are you okay?" he asked. "Yup," I replied. "Have you had enough?" "No," I lied. Then he did a loop, flying the plane in a full circle in the air. I know many people would find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. However, I thought it was a bit too much. At the top of the loop, while flying upside down, I heard a small voice saying, "Relax, relax, look up." I looked up and saw some fields. The flight lasted 10 minutes. It was "soft" compared to what the pilots experience during a race. To show this, Dario took out some sandwiches as soon as we landed and happily ate them. I didn’t eat for hours, and that night, I dreamed of doing loops over and over again.

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you've ever seen amazing footage of polar bears in a nature documentary, it was probably filmed by him. He says his ideal temperature is -18C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first passion, where he learned how to survive in cold places. His big opportunity came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. 'I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours I realized that being a wildlife cameraman was perfect for me: travel, adventure, underwater.' He is now a top cameraman and has worked on many major TV wildlife series. 'I started at a good time. When I began, hardly anyone had been to the Antarctic. You had people who specialized in coral, elephants, chimpanzees. I just became the cold man. It was like all these amazing scenes were just waiting to be filmed.' The camera and communications technology was very basic when he started 35 years ago. 'It is certainly easier to film today. If you shot something then, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can shoot a lot and look at it immediately. You used to have to think about what shots you needed next, and what you had missed. You shot less. Film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material.' 'My value is field experience in cold conditions. I have a feel for it. I have spent so much time on sea ice it now feels like crossing the street. I do get cold toes but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases or mosquitoes.' Wildlife filming, Allan says, is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes. Unfortunately, he could not identify which birds they were. When Allan recently got permission to film sequences for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he did not expect an easy assignment. It is a world of polar bears and is strictly off limits to all but the most fearless or foolish. Usually -32C in April, the wind is vicious and hauling cameras in the deep snow is a nightmare. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow slopes for 23 days, however, Allan had seen just one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, though, he says, he was living in bear world, at bear speed, with bear senses. 'We find a new hole and wait. We shuffle, hop, bend, stretch and run to stay warm. Five hours of watching and then with no warning at all I catch a glimpse so brief that I almost miss it. But the camera's locked on the hole on full zoom and my eye's very quickly on the viewfinder. Nothing for a couple of seconds and then an unmistakable black nose. Nose becomes muzzle, grows bigger to become full head and in less than a minute she has her front legs out and is resting on the snow in front of the hole. She's looking at me but she's not bothered. I've just pulled out of a close-up thinking this can't get much better … when she sets off on a long slide down the slope. I'd swear it's partly in sheer pleasure,' he recounts, adding that two cubs then appeared at the den entrance. 'Clearly it's their first view of the world … It's show time on the slopes and we have front-row seats.' Now Allan would like to make his own film about climate change in the Arctic, talking to the people who live there and experience the impact of it first hand. He says he would be able to make an extraordinary documentary.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk to the North Pole alone without getting more supplies on the way. He had to swim through freezing waters and deal with frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole too. Now, he is back in the Arctic, getting ready for an even more challenging expedition. Explorers are confident and determined people, and they need to be. This time, there is much more at risk. Pen and two colleagues will go on a three-month, 1,000-kilometer journey to the North Pole, measuring the thickness and density of the ice. No one has done this before, and the results will be very important for scientists. This will give the clearest picture yet of how global warming is affecting the polar ice. Pen was trained for this kind of work. As a child, he was looked after by a woman who had worked for the famous explorer Scott of the Antarctic. She was hired to make him tough by sending him out into blizzards and icy winds with very few clothes. His father shared a love of icy adventures with him, and Pen showed unusual physical strength. Pen is married to Mary, who loves the outdoors too. She helps run his polar guide business and says she worries more about him when he’s at home because he’s often thinking about the Arctic. For fun, she once raced against him in a mountain event where riders on horseback compete against people on foot. Mary and her horse finished an hour before Pen. Pen and Mary live in the countryside with their two children. ‘It’s much harder to be away from them this time,’ he admits. ‘They were one and five when I last went, and I made a mistake in the way I said goodbye. I thought it would be a good idea to say to my son, “You’re the man of the house now, look after your mum and your sister.” He absolutely took it to heart, asking his mum how she was all the time, but the strain eventually became too much. While it was well intentioned, it was an unfair thing to do.’ For similar reasons he is planning to have very little contact with them while in the Arctic. ‘If you call them you remind them how far away you are.’ He is spending these last days before departure preparing his kit, obsessively. ‘Out on the ice, one is virtually incapable of mending things or doing anything that isn’t absolutely straightforward,’ he says. With him will be Ann Daniels, one of the world’s leading polar explorers, and the expedition photographer, Martin Hartley. They will be supported by a crew of six, flying in supplies. Being part of a team is actually more stressful to someone with his mentality, says Pen, and something else is on his mind too. ‘I’m going to be 47 on Thursday. I’ve done far less training than I’m comfortable with.’ Why? ‘Organisational things always seem more urgent. So I’m almost fearful of what I’m going to ask of myself.’ Pen believes his mission reconnects exploration with the search for knowledge that drove previous generations into the unknown. ‘Making it to the North Pole was ultimately a personal ambition,’ he admits, ‘and of limited value to anyone beyond the polar adventuring community. This time, scientists will profit from the data, and we’re creating a platform in which to engage as many people as possible in what’s happening in the Arctic Ocean. This is important work, and nobody can do it but us,’ he says. ‘Our skills, which are otherwise bizarre and socially redundant, have become hyper-relevant. Suddenly, we’re socially useful again.’

I took a year off and wondered what to do next. Being an Olympian is amazing, and I had opportunities to write, work on TV, and speak at schools and businesses. Although these activities were interesting, I missed having a competitive challenge. I wanted to stay fit in case I decided to compete in the Olympics again, so I started running marathons and doing triathlons. But there was still Ben Fogle's invitation in my mind: "Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?" I love rowing and missed the feeling of the boat gliding through the water, but I wasn't ready to train every day. I talked to some rowing friends about the race, but they weren't interested. I knew if I joined, I would want to win, even though it was more of an adventure. I wasn't sure if Ben was the best partner to win with, but the idea of being an underdog was appealing. 

Ben was already planning to do the race and had managed to gather the entry fee and deposit for a boat, making the race a real possibility. We discussed the remaining costs, which were high, with the boat and equipment alone costing £70,000. We thought we had a good chance, but it would require effort to secure everything. Besides the race expenses, I also had to consider the loss of income from being away. Speaking at business events is a good way to earn money as a retired athlete, and it's nice that people are interested. However, I find it hard to talk about past achievements without a new goal. Doing the race would give me something current to talk about: rowing across the Atlantic.

Planning this adventure taught me to appreciate the simpler life of a full-time athlete. Preparing for the Olympics was tough, but straightforward, with set training programs and support from doctors and dieticians. I was worried about how people would react to me racing with a TV presenter, thinking it might seem like I just wanted to be on TV. But during our preparations, my concerns faded. The Atlantic Rowing Race is more about mental strength than just rowing skills. Ben had done tough challenges before, like the Marathon des Sables and spending time at sea and on a deserted island. However, he wasn't a natural rower, and I was surprised by his lack of skill. I could have been more patient, but I needed to be honest about the improvements he needed. I should have expected his level when I agreed to race with him.

Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle, in the far north of Finland. At 26, I felt restless and dreamed of the cold, empty Arctic landscapes, maybe as a reaction to the noisy, crowded life in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They agreed to hire me as a husky dog handler for a busy winter season. From December to February, they have many tourists who want sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, lasting from an hour to five days. They started with six dogs, which quickly grew to over 100. Recently, they took over a second place called the 'wilderness farm', which they said was a beautiful but simple place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months if I understood what I was getting into. 'The hours are long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical.’ I started packing right away.

November 6, London On my flight, I try to memorize the names of over 100 huskies, but I feel distracted and nervous. I put the list down and look out the window instead. People say that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, like a wave of blooming flowers and leaves. But I feel like I am seeing the opposite, with winter moving south and rivers freezing.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta The bus ride north is everything I hoped for. We drive through endless dark forests of thin conifers, heavy with snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrive at the farm after dark and am immediately given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. 'Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?’ Anna asks. It’s a rhetorical question. I follow the barking, which becomes very loud as I reach the dog sheds. Three people are running back and forth, harnessing the huskies to sleds. The dogs are almost crazy with excitement, pulling hard against the ropes, eager to go. I can barely hear to introduce myself, but the others are too busy to talk much anyway. I stand on the side and pet one of the quieter dogs. Someone gestures at me impatiently – 'Get in!’ – and I almost fall into the nearest sled. A command is given, and with a jerk, we are off into the dark, with only a head torch for light.

November 15, Hetta It doesn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but first, I face tough questions about what I can contribute. 'Are you useful?’ Anna asks. I’m unsure. Am I? More questions show that no, I am not: I have never driven a snowmobile, haven’t done woodwork since school, and have never chopped anything with an axe. 'You do have a driving licence?’ someone asks finally. I nod, relieved. The basics of dog-sledding can be learned quickly: lean into the corners, put both feet on the brake to stop, and, no matter what, don’t let go of the handlebar. But everything else seems very complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs become very hard in freezing temperatures. A bowl of water will freeze solid while you watch, so we must make a 'soup’ of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, my head is full of instructions, and my muscles ache from dragging heavy sleds and being pulled around by eager huskies. But I feel triumphant. 'I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw,’ I email friends. 'In the snow.’

On that day, when Radcliffe crossed the finish line, the media gathered to understand her amazing run. Her time was so good that it would allow her to compete in the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about the benefits of emu oil, a natural treatment. Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had recommended it to help heal injuries from an accident when Radcliffe ran into a bike while training. Radcliffe says the achievement never really felt real to her. Looking back, she realizes it was a big deal at the time. However, she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day, so it didn't overwhelm her. She and her team had decided not to set any limits. Their motto was: no limits. During the race, her husband and coach, Gary Lough, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio. Next to him was Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent wondered if she could maintain such a fast pace. He worried it might cause her to drop out of the race. Hartmann was upset by this, although he admitted that anyone who didn't know how fit she was might think it was risky to start so fast. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe started to calculate. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she crossed the line in less than three minutes. She had run 41 kilometers at an incredible speed but still managed to sprint the last part in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." She remembers the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he didn't think anyone would come close to that time for a while. And she thought, "I'm going to come back and do it next year." Unfortunately, that didn't happen. After the race, everyone wanted to know how an athlete with such an awkward running style had beaten the graceful East African runners. Hartmann had stayed with Radcliffe for weeks, giving her daily sessions to help with the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He says, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could handle that level of pain. She would push me to go so deep into her muscles that I had to ice my thumbs afterward because I was in so much pain." Hartmann describes traveling 13 hours from Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no "Hello Gerard, do you want a cup of tea?" He had barely arrived, and she was ready for a two-hour session. Paula would push him to give everything he had. That's what made her so good. During that time, Hartmann spent so much time with Radcliffe that his other athletes became resentful. Can Radcliffe explain why no one has come close to her record? "Not really. I trained very hard, but there are people who are more talented. I thought it might happen with Mary Keitany (two-time London marathon winner). Maybe it's because people are racing each other more than racing themselves." What does she mean? "That mental approach of never easing up, even when you've won the race, probably pushed me to it because I never thought, 'I can relax now.' It was always: 'keep pushing as hard as you can.'" Radcliffe didn't know it then, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She would never run as fast again. However, she left a lasting legacy. Many women were inspired to take up long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, "In Search of Perfection," was released, I was unsure how viewers and the media would react. At that time, there was a lot of talk about a food 'revolution' happening in Britain. I believed our show added something new to this movement, but I still worried: would people like a cooking show that included not just techniques, but also history, nostalgia, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both happy and scared. I needn't have worried. The show's success led to many other exciting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project feels like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I then wrote several books in a series called "Perfection," each with its own TV show. In these, the journey was often very physical, involving travel with passports and suitcases. "In Search of Total Perfection" is the latest in the series, where you travel the world to meet extraordinary people, like a man who dedicates his life to making the best-tasting golden pasta. These people have spent years chasing their own ideas of perfection. Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew some people would be upset if their favorite dish was left out. I could imagine people asking, "Where's steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?" However, after long discussions, the TV team and I created a list that had something for everyone. This confirmed my belief that everyone has their own idea of perfection, based on personal emotions, memories, and surroundings. Despite the book's title, I never claimed the recipes were 'definitive.' But I thought that by using my skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. The dictionary defines 'perfection' as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. Trying ideas and refining them until they become unique. The TV series allowed me to explore foods, people, and places I had never seen in any restaurant, and I was as excited about that as I was about exploring memory and nostalgia in food because that's how I started in this business. Finding the best ingredients for the recipes took me around the world. Some of my adventures included being taken to a canning factory that processed the wrong type of tomato and visiting a dairy farm with standards so low we had to stop filming. Perfecting each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow and using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken breasts in a hospital scanning machine, and nearly burning my house down trying to get the oven hot enough for a proper Neapolitan-style pizza.

We were still a few hours away from Marrakech when the van suddenly made a loud noise and swerved off the road into a field, coming to a stop. John got out and looked under the hood of the van. He stood there for a long time, looking at the engine with his hands in his pockets, pretending to know what he was doing. Finally, he admitted, "Actually, I have no idea what I'm doing," and he and Mum started laughing. Bea was worried and said, "We can't stay here forever." The field was vast, with nothing but grass and lots of flowers like poppies and daisies. I agreed with Bea because it was always safest to be on her side. We both got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John walk away, getting smaller and smaller as he went to find someone who knew about cars. Mum lay down on the grass and asked me to tell a story. Bea lay down next to her and encouraged me to tell one. So, I told them about how, the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I shared everything the birds talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and even an argument over a worm. Bea said, "That's silly, no one understands bird language." My eyes stung, and I insisted, "I do," but I didn't sound convincing. "Liar," she said, and I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered every word? The more I thought about it, the less sure I was. "Mum...?" But she had fallen asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to a hotel. Bea refused to get out, but the boys didn't mind. They waved and smiled at her through the back door windows. We followed John into a café near where our van was parked. "It's a hotel," John whispered. "I think it might be expensive." "We'll just have some tea," Mum reassured him, and we sat down in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot and said, "It's like syrup in there." We stayed at the café all day while John tried to fix the engine. "I suppose it's a miracle it got us this far," he said as it got dark. Mum spread blankets on the ground in the hotel garden for us to sleep. It was nice to sleep on ground that wasn't moving. "I'll have to get us towed into Marrakech," John said. Later, we were in a truck watching our van being towed behind us with John at the wheel. At first, Bea didn't want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. She sat in the front with the driver. I kept wondering how we would get home now that our van needed to be towed everywhere. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists who were playing at the Prague Classical Music Festival. Unlike Lucy, they were not competing. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city, but Lucy didn't catch her name because of the noise. It was something like Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke English well enough to discuss the music they were playing, their recent travels, and their future plans. 

Lucy mentioned she might be going to the Tanglewood festival that summer, which sounded impressive. However, she didn't really want to go. She often felt this way about the concerts and competitions that took her around the world, causing her to miss so much school that she wasn't officially enrolled anymore. Instead, she studied with tutors from the University of San Francisco. Lucy hadn't even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists in her age group from around the world. Out of thousands of applicants, she was chosen. Her dad celebrated by buying her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant, and her little brother Gus dreamed of attending the festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. 

The truth was, Lucy hadn't applied to the festival herself. Her mother had filled out the application and sent in a CD. Her mom said she didn't want Lucy to be disappointed if she didn't get in. Lucy thought it was more about not giving her the chance to say no. At that time, Lucy believed that causing trouble was the worst thing she could do, so she didn't even think about trying to back out.

The guy from Tokyo seemed surprised when Lucy mentioned Tanglewood. "How old are you?" he asked. "Fifteen," she replied. He exchanged a look with Liesel/Louisa, who said, "Wow." Lucy hadn't meant to show off. It was hard to know when sharing her achievements was just fitting in or bragging. "It's just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they're trying..." she explained. Liesel/Louisa excused herself, looking across the room as if she saw someone she needed to talk to. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked if Lucy had ever been to Japan. He had long, shaggy hair, like many male musicians, to show they were rebels. "Once. When I was, like, eight," Lucy replied. 

Just then, Lucy's grandfather appeared and interrupted. "Lucy, let me introduce you to someone," he said, pulling her away. "And don't get too friendly with the competition." "They're not the competition," Lucy replied. "Everyone is the competition," her grandfather insisted. He took her around the room, making her talk to people he thought were important. Lucy smiled and nodded, only half-listening to what was said.

In the elevator to their suite after the party, her grandfather told her, "You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and there’s a buzz about you. They all know who you are." Lucy liked that part—being somebody. Even if it meant some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention she got. Being a concert pianist didn't earn her any special respect from the kids she used to go to school with. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn't know or care that she could play a Rachmaninov allegro perfectly. But in places like this festival, she knew she mattered.

Dad said, "Spending too much time online isn't good for you. You need to experience the real world." It's hard to argue with him, so I looked into what experts say about this topic, and it's quite interesting. Research generally shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are learning important technical skills needed for the digital age. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says social networking is now a key part of growing up. Teenagers don't just use media occasionally like adults do; they live in it. It's not about whether it's good or bad, but how you use it that matters.

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did at our age? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it's like the modern version of hanging out at a youth club, which today's parents did when they were younger. It helps teenagers develop their identity away from their parents and learn to deal with teenage issues and interact with peers.

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson explains that adolescence is a time for asking, "Who am I?" Social networking can help develop self-identity by allowing you to share your favorite music or sports, discover what you enjoy, and see different perspectives. Research shows that active social networkers are less self-centered than those who don't use social media. He also mentions that social media can be helpful for shy people, as online communication can be more comfortable than face-to-face interactions.

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can be beneficial for quiet individuals with specific interests, as they allow connections with others who share those interests. For example, if only a few people at your school like a certain type of music, you might feel isolated. But finding a group online with similar interests can make you feel more connected.

Pauline White, a digital education expert, says that young people who find new interests online, join like-minded networks, and create their own content are truly using the potential of social networks. She believes social networking is becoming a creative force, with teenagers making videos, podcasts, and blogs about their interests. Photo-sharing sites are enhancing creativity by allowing photographers to connect, learn, and share images. This can improve employability and be beneficial in the workplace. Every business uses social media to sell and increase brand awareness, so understanding how it works is important. For example, if you create a product and have 1,000 friends on social networks, they could be potential customers. Linking these networks can build your customer base.

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they enter the workforce, agrees Matthews. Many sites offer opportunities to collaborate and share content, which is a valuable 21st-century skill and important for being employable in a digital age.

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they probably don't imagine a long road trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. But my parents had a different idea for our summer vacation this year. My dad decided to plan what many teenagers would consider a nightmare: a big family bonding trip. Before we left, my parents kept saying, "Not enough people do this anymore," while my twin brother and I exchanged worried looks, thinking, "There's probably a good reason for that!"

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and clothes for all kinds of weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. I had some ideas on how to cope, though. With barely enough space left for us in the car, we started our "Family Great American Road Trip." As we left our comfortable home for smaller accommodations over the next five thousand miles, I wasn't the only one wondering what we were getting into.

We headed west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had some adventures. We stopped for the night near a town in Oklahoma, under some of the darkest, star-filled skies in the country, but only after almost being blown off the highway by a dust storm. We quickly learned that on the road, cattle have the right-of-way!

The next day, we were up at dawn and on the move again. I noticed a pattern forming. The desert turned into mountains. The days started to blend together, but each adventure was unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and moved on to Pagosa Springs, Colorado. The strong smell of sulfur in that friendly tourist town gave us a hint of what was to come later in our trip. As we climbed to our next destination, we learned that roads marked for Jeeps are best left to Jeep drivers. Everywhere we stopped, we saw a mix of ancient and modern. Dodging construction traffic became normal. We laughed as we posed by the big "CLOSED" signs at the Four Corners Monument.

We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. "Bear jams," where traffic stops to let a bear cross, were common, and park volunteers managed them. Our own close encounter with a bear on the road, and an anxious park ranger, gave us unforgettable memories.

As we continued, life back home seemed far away, and even the old hotel we stayed in, with its creaky floors and no internet or cell phone service, couldn't dampen our spirits. In exchange, I got to see some of the most beautiful views ever. After watching a rainstorm from our cozy hotel in Canada, we headed back south. My parents were right. You don't need to go to an exotic foreign place to find something amazing. It was bittersweet to be home again, but at least I hadn't fought with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our crazy journey to look through and remember. And I knew that for me, the best memories would be the unplanned, spontaneous moments.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years because her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, were staying in England. Amy would finish her last year of school, living under the care of the college Head. It was important for Amy to stay because it was her final year, and she was happy to have the best room at the college, complete with a kitchen and study area, plus free Internet and phone access. Jeff and Dahlia would still keep an eye on Amy.

Rose was moving to her grandmother's house. She only had vague holiday memories of her grandmother and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not very excited, but Daisy insisted it was no trouble and wanted to reconnect with her granddaughter. Rose didn't fully understand why her parents had issues with Daisy, but there had been a disagreement in the past, which meant they spent holidays elsewhere. Rose was ten when she last saw Daisy, but her memories were happy. Dahlia said living with Daisy would be interesting because Daisy was very social and liked bringing people together. Rose expected to receive dinner invitations, coffee morning requests, and shopping trips soon. This made Rose smile because Daisy was not a typical frail grandmother; she seemed to attend more social events than the Queen of England.

Before moving, Dahlia and Rose had a talk. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, staying fit, and getting enough sleep. But Rose wanted independence. She wanted to play loud music, invite friends over, or go out without always asking for permission. She didn't want to be nagged about homework or staying out late, and she didn't want to be dragged around by her grandmother. Daisy understood this. Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen mobile phone with a video camera for emergencies, which made Rose very happy. They agreed that trust was important. Daisy would trust Rose to act maturely, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If either of them crossed the line, they would talk about it.

Rose had never been a troublemaker. Her school friends were similar, so her school reports and exam results were always good. This helped her. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and basically start her life over. It was her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced at this. At least she knew this was the last time, as she would be starting her final two years at school. For Rose, it was a new beginning, a new piece in the puzzle of her life.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book was a big achievement because it seemed difficult, and she wasn't interested in other activities like the Olympics. At 13, she decided to try writing a novel. Now, that novel is about to be published. When she told her former teacher, the teacher was surprised, thinking Charlotte would write a book at 30 or 40. Charlotte didn't see why she should wait to do something she might be good at.

We meet on a winter afternoon at her publisher's office. Even though I knew I was meeting a 15-year-old author, it was still surprising to see a teenager there. Her book is impressive: the story is confident and full of action. Nothing about it, except the heroine's age, suggests it was written by a teenager. A public relations person is with us in case Charlotte needs help, but she is independent and confident, with a lively intelligence and a calmness that keeps her grounded.

Charlotte admits she is young and doesn't have all the answers. When I ask about the complex moral issues in her book, she says, "I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I can't offer many life lessons to my readers," she laughs. "I don't think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I'm not particularly wise either. I just wanted to explore the theme of taking responsibility."

She has a theory about how teenagers are portrayed in books. She believes there are three types: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who lacks social skills. Reading about these types frustrated her. "What if you're basically fine? There aren't many stories about characters who aren't flawed in some way. Some writers unintentionally suggest that teenagers can't know who they are because they lack experience, which can hurt their self-confidence."

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy writers, but they almost discouraged her from writing. "Books by my favorite fantasy authors explore deep psychological and life themes. I wondered if I needed to do the same to write a good book and if I was capable of it." However, she appreciates a book called How Not to Write a Novel, which advises that if readers can predict what happens next, the suspense is lost.

Some might think Charlotte's parents, both journalists, helped her get published. Her father's connection in publishing did help get her book read initially. She knows she's lucky because getting a first novel read is tough, no matter the author's age. "Every writer needs support and a lucky break, but after that, you're on your own. Writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don't take things for granted," Charlotte concludes.

Text: "‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then David, who had some experience in freestyle ski-jumping and wanted to show he knew what he was doing, went first. He skied down the slope towards the jump quickly. As he flew into the air, his arms were flailing. Even we could see something was wrong. We held our breath. He landed, lost both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly told us, ‘speed is unpredictable.’ Maybe I wasn’t meant for this freestyle skiing. On past skiing holidays, I liked practicing turns in the snow. I wasn’t one of those teenagers doing tricks on ramps and half pipes in skateboard parks. I thought it looked fun, but I didn’t know how to do it, and I was afraid of being laughed at. Then my parents decided we’d have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a big indoor area near the slopes, with trampolines and ski jumps covered in fake snow. Students would jump, try new tricks, and land in foam pits – not a real introduction to what we’d face on the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just go down the slopes and hope for the best,’ said Gareth. ‘But remember – if you hit the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat part behind the jump before the slope gets steep again. If you land in the right zone, you keep moving forward, which is less painful. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. That’s why you need speed. At first, it was hard to make my body ignore my brain and go fast towards the jump. My legs would almost stop as I got close, so I landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday I felt shorter. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ said Gareth. Day two started on the trampolines. I thought I’d hate being indoors, looking at the snowy peaks outside, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some exercises copied ski-jumping moves, others taught ‘aerial awareness’ – knowing what your body is doing in the air. Gareth gave us feedback. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed work – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off, and then I was in the foam cubes. We went back to the mountain to try again. There were more setbacks before I finally landed properly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a moment I felt proud of reaching such a difficult goal. But that didn’t last long. On the last run of the day, I kept my speed as I approached the jump, flew into the air, and landed in the right zone. Then I saw both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer on my feet."

Imagine you're on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty with fear, and you're gripping the harness tightly. The ride stops suddenly, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs upwards. There's a pause, then a sudden drop, and you feel your stomach lift. You speed forward, turn sharply left, and go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you scream from deep inside. But you chose this: like millions of others each year, you paid to enter the theme park.

It's interesting that amusement parks, with their thrilling rides, are such a big industry. To create the excitement and escape people want, there are large teams of creative and maybe slightly cruel engineers and designers working behind the scenes. Being a 'rollercoaster designer' might sound like a child's dream job, but it's actually very challenging. Designers must create the right mix of fun and fear while keeping passengers safe, and they need to add new features to keep visitors coming back.

Many people think rollercoasters have become more intense over time, but most techniques used today were invented by John Miller, a US designer, in the early 20th century. Back then, rollercoasters were more extreme, but now designers are limited by the track designs from specialist manufacturers.

I talked to three rollercoaster experts. Professor Brendan Walker, a 'thrill engineer,' said the skill is in putting the pieces together. Dr. John Roberts, from the Royal Academy of Engineering, explained that it's about quickly switching between different forces so people feel thrown around but safe. It's a fine line between thrilling and uncomfortable.

To create an amazing ride, teams must build a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, and combine it with new features like the tallest ride or the most twists. However, Professor Walker said that in the end, gut instincts, experience, and trial-and-error are key. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed that being a thrill-seeker helps designers understand what passengers want and test rides before they open to the public.

I asked if new technology, like virtual reality, will change rollercoaster design. Walker said not to expect too much. Virtual reality can add a layer of excitement, like painting an old rollercoaster, but the physical ride experience will remain the most important for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already accomplished a lot as a choreographer, creating pieces for many theatres and dance companies. She also still dances occasionally. I wonder why she fits both activities into her busy schedule. She explains, "Dancing again reminds me of what it's like to be in the studio, taking orders from demanding choreographers, and how tense and frustrating that can be. Choreographers can forget what it's like to rehearse all day." As a choreographer, she enjoys teaching and working with young students. "A new dancer is often open to exploring new ideas. In some ways, working with students is easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want success but don't fully know their strengths and weaknesses yet. This incomplete understanding makes them accept even harsh criticism. They might challenge me sometimes, but I welcome their honest feedback."

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her work. "There might be music I'm not fond of, but I still create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don't respond well to a certain composer's music, it can be frustrating, but I have to find solutions. I can't just choose a new piece. Ideally, I'd like to be more experimental and switch to different pieces, which would help lift the mood during tough rehearsals. Unfortunately, I'm always working on big productions where the musical score is already set by the composer and can't be changed."

Miranda doesn't like to attach herself to one institution. "I think it's important to keep meeting new people. But I have to remember that all the theatres and schools I work with have different methods and styles. So I have to adapt my work each time I go somewhere new, instead of doing the same thing. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways."

We talk about a recent documentary on professional ballet dancers and choreographers. "There have been glamorous documentaries before that were misleading," says Miranda. "This one really tries to show viewers what life is like inside a dance company. There was a scene where a young dancer gets endless corrections, and I smiled in recognition. She knows she's not getting it right but can't make her body do what's needed. It's painful to watch but not staged for the cameras. The public underestimates the amount of work and dedication involved in ballet."

I'm curious about what makes a great ballet or dance production for Miranda. "It's when everything the company has invested in – the music, the costumes, the lighting, and the dancers – all come together. Perfection might be too much to ask for, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can make up for a few wrong artistic choices. I've been in productions where the dance steps are great, but something about the costumes or props is distracting. That's disappointing."

Miranda has done a wide range of work, so I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? "People want to label you, and I don't understand that. There's also a trend to develop expertise in a narrow area. I don't follow that, though I might one day be happy to be known for one thing. For now, I just want to broaden my horizons."

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on TV. I agreed that TV shows amazing things, but why stay at home when there's so much to experience outside? That conversation inspired my unusual four-day trip and a film to encourage people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of an old sofa, which became the main feature of the film. I attached three wheels and some cables to it and used old seatbelts to secure myself. I put my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, even spending one night on the beach. Several friends joined me along the way, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to continue. I've been on many walking trips recently, but this was completely different. It was the longest distance I've ever walked, and it was on main roads. This meant I could stop at a roadside café and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino, instead of having the wind blow away my sandwiches while sitting on a rock. I often had to tell people, "No, I'm not doing it for charity, and I'm not training for a marathon." When someone at work asks about my weekend, I'd rather talk about dragging a sofa 100 miles across southern England than discuss the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I was excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually traveled with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday might be a good idea. At the Greek port, the man seemed curious when I asked for a single ferry ticket because the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn't be alone for long; I’d be joining ten others to swim around the tiny islands. Although he still looked puzzled, he let me on board with a smile. Our group had exchanged emails before we left, but there was little time to chat before our first group swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would be with us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, then it was time for our first proper 1.5 km swim, and I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but never long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I was at the back of the slow group—not where I wanted to be. I watched faster swimmers moving ahead like dolphins. I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was happy when I finally did it on my own. The following days had a routine: jumping in, reaching a comfortable speed, and stopping to admire the scenery. As the swims got longer, so did my speed and enjoyment. There seemed little need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come again next year.

Being a flight attendant isn't easy, but it's a job I love. Since I started, I've traveled all over, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have lots of free time, and life is never dull. It's perfect for someone young like me! As a child, I went to a boarding school abroad, so I often flew alone. I felt lonely and would ask flight attendants if I could help serve meals, and some let me. This memory stayed with me when I wanted to leave my banking job and find a new path. At the interview, there were many young people, and lots of them got accepted. They were often well-qualified and changing careers, just like me. I practiced what to say before the interview, focusing on my strengths and past work experience, not just my love for travel. This helped me get the job! I recommend this work to anyone because there are many benefits, though free flights aren't the main one. Airline staff work very hard, and there's a saying: "no-one's finished till everyone’s finished." It's like a big family. Even if we don't see each other often, we're still close. When I'm not working, I don't have to think about work. And if I do encounter difficult passengers, which doesn't happen often, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won't see them again!

At the summer camp where I work, I love watching the children succeed at things they never thought they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they arrive, but rock climbing is new for many of them. Some children feel very nervous, but with some encouragement, they agree to try, and eventually, they all reach the top. This achievement makes them feel really good. 

At the start of the week, some children miss home. Surprisingly, it's not the youngest ones who feel this way the most; it's usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We don't let them use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. Then, when they ask again after dinner, we say it's a bit late to call now and suggest they do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a couple of days, and by the end of the week, they thank us because they've had a great time.

It's not just the children who feel lonely. Sometimes, parents call us a lot, asking how their child is doing, which isn't really necessary. Often, their child is busy playing games or doing other activities, so we have to ask the parents to call back later. We also often see a certain type of child who comes dressed in expensive new clothes. These children usually argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why it's necessary.

"Rock the Planet" is a musical show where the actors also need to be great musicians. It started in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won 'Best Musical' four times. Doing the show with only British actors was difficult because the UK has stricter rules about how many shows young actors can do each week. In the USA, they can do more shows. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors in the UK, and they have just won their first 'Best Musical' award. The London theatre is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night because everyone wants to hear the songs that were first popular in America.

I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, "It's amazing that I get paid to play, especially on a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar." He explained how busy the young actors are. "We have regular school lessons every day at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends." I asked what his friends think of the show. "My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it's expensive for them," he said.

When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found an extra one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called "Days," which I didn't know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I was happy when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie's talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show's director wasn't there to hear my mistakes!

The young actors were already musicians, and some could play several instruments, but none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were concentrating so much that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it's definitely worth seeing.
